author: John Lovell

text: The reason manufactures do this is because consumers are demanding more and more things in their vehicles.  Where are you going to put all those buttons and knobs without 1) making the interior look ugly and ridiculous and 2) without adding to the problem of distractions.  Searching through a million hard buttons and switches is even more dangerous than touchscreen.  The problem is most people don’t bother with even glancing at the owner’s manual to at least get an idea of where things are.  They get in the car and just drive, them when they need the wipers or something like the defrosters they instantly panic because they don’t know where those controls are.﻿

I know if I reach down to the  console in my A5 by the gear shift, just by feel, I can adjust the NAV/Radio/AC without taking my eyes off the road. A physical jog shuttle in the centre with four buttons round it, I know what to do just by feel. You cant do that with a touch screen. You physically have to take your eyes off the road to access the menu/apps on the screen. It is the same as using a cell phone, but perfectly legal (yet dangerous) where car manufacturers install them﻿

text:
@reginald burks bullshit.  HUDs are fine, but a rectangle popping up out of the dash is a complete eyesore and poor visual design/flow.  You can have your a-pillar gauge pods, extra tachs drilled into your dash, and an ipad like thing sticking up out of the dash; I'll prefer a clean look.

Why are you looking at that display constantly?  What purpose?  You need to stare at a gps to use it to get anywhere?  How'd you get on before gps?  You need to stare at it to listen to the radio?

The tesla/prius prime screen is nice, and well integrated, but I'm not going to take my PC monitor and hot glue it to the top of my dash so I can tune the radio.

I didn't notice this bullshit until I started researching recent cars, I will never buy a car with some shit like that.

I don't even have to look at the the speedometer all the time, because when you know your car, you innately know your speed.  And if you are talking about taking eyes off road?  Then I suppose you aren't checking your side mirrors regularly, and the rearview mirror must be too high for you as well.

HUDs compared to a tacky display sticking up like a sore thumb ...  I can't even ffs﻿

author: TruthYnot

text:
EVs shouldn't even be included in modern cars. Electric Cars is the next generation push that is going to revolutionize the way we drive. It is unfortunate Tesla is making EVs look bad by forcing self-driving that doesn't need to happen right now. Elon Musk though is the only person that is attempting to push EVs to become the new standard.

There is nothing wrong with using gas-fueled cars but we are that time gas-fueled cars is slowly losing the market growth because they all the same and no reason to buy a new one. Gas-fueled cars is expected to die in the next century. It is better start moving foward with EVs. With EVs, we stop paying so much money for usless fuel and put growth into extending our technology make sure the market growth blooms again as if car manufactures were born for the first time.

Touchscreens, Electric-Doors, Keyless, app-controlled buttons, smarter-interface for driver, smarter-engine, smarter-operating system. In due time, electric-controlled brain of a car will solve main issues we struggle today. Century from now, EVs will reduce crashing, hitting nearby cars/people, faster reaction-time, better speed, and safer air-filtration.

If we keep thinking EVs will be backwards, higher-risk, potential-hack, making people dumber, etc. We are going to slowly lose the economic growth of car industry.﻿

author: John T

text: @John T Sure, volume is on the wheel (I only used it as an example) but when you're in a turn, if you need to turn the volume down, it's not as simple when it's on a steering wheel, especially when some cars (like the Impala I rented last week) put it on the back side of the wheel.  When the knob is in a fixed position, it's always in the same spot, making it easier to access regardless of what else is going on.﻿
author: SuperN0va

text:
@SuperN0va You shouldn't be messing with the volume while turning regardless but I can see them adding voice commands in the future. 

90% of my miles are on Autopilot so it doesn't really affect me.﻿
author: John T

text: @John T If you're negotiating a left hand turn in the turning lane and you have the light, it doesn't require both hands to just hold the wheel.  Maybe a super loud ad has come on and it's blasting your ear drums.  Maybe you thought you heard a siren wailing, and you want to be sure you're not going to be in the way after you exit the intersection, so you turn down the radio.  A child in the back seat shrieks in pain, and you need to quickly assess the situation.  There's plenty of reasons why you might need to be able to quickly reach for a volume knob (or stupid buttons on the steering wheel), even while during a turn.  Most of my miles are on the highway or in the air, but when I'm driving between worksites for a single job, I'm definitely on city streets or access roads (which I hate) quite a bit.﻿

author: Arthur Magalhaes
Kalvinjj

text:
@audiopendent Glue on the polarizer films degrade, and the LCD DOES have the liquid crystal inside it's two sheets of glass. Sorry to tell you it's not just marketing, the polarization changing substance there is indeed liquid. This liquid also doesn't react too well with strongly varying temperatures, it can temporarily fade or go slow, usually both. Leave an LCD desk clock on the sun and tell me of you see it working properly. Winter in Europe doesn't count, proper heat, that DOES happen inside a car.
Meanwhile the liquid crystal itself doesn't usually leak, the degraded glue does, and makes a sticky mess inside the screen and possibly outside it too. Picture becomes trash.﻿

author: Peter Killeen

text:
THANK YOU ... THANK YOU ... THANK YOU!!! for this great video.

I am in the market to replace my recently totaled 1998 Toyota Corolla and I'll be blunt: I can't stand the new 2014 to 2020 Corollas or pretty much many of the new similar-type cars today and the reason is simple.  The manufacturers are designing into these new cars so many "added features" to compensate for designedin problems and creating newer consumer dangers.

I'd buy a new 1998 Toyota Corolla in a heartbeat because:

1. Reliability: The car had most of it's major parts in perfectly fine working and serviceable order after 21 years including the engine (though it burnt and leaked oil after 10 years), the transmission, the A/C and coolant system, the braking system, the exhaust system, all the electronics from the radio to the lights, etc.  I drove it over 206,000 miles without a single major safety issue and likely could have driven it for up to 300,000 miles.  It never left me stranded.
2.  Visibility: I could see the entire car from the driver's seat simply by a look in the mirror or a slight or fuller turn of my head or body (if I had to back up) and I could see everything and everyone around me.  There were nearly no blindspots, except for the typical right rear corner.
3.  Simplicity: There were just enough simple and basic "bells and whistles, buttons and lights" to make the car easy to use without distracting noises, lights that would cause you to take your eyes off the road, and easily breakable electronics.
4.  Fixability: The car had mostly easy to access mechanical items when needing to fix either a usual wearable external part or a more challenging internal part.
5.  Cost of Use: I drove around 12,000 miles to 15,000 miles per year and the car usually cost me very little per year unless a major item needed to be serviced like the timing belt after 100,000 miles.
6.  Gas Mileage: I could easily get over 300 highway miles on this car, 250 miles around town.
7.  Paint and Body: The car had lots of chipped paint on the front of the hood from being hit from pebbles on the ground after 21 years, but there wasn't an ounce of rust on the visible body of the car, though of course there was some underneath.  The carpeting and seat covers and seat cushions were all in perfect condition after 21 years.

The biggest problem I've noticed with these new cars, especially the 2014 to 2020 Corollas is that they are designed to be driven as if you're a fighter pilot in an aerial dog fight.

Manufacturers are designing in "blind spots" in cars like the thicker front "A-Columns" and "C-Columns" for the airbags and using smaller windows in the process as if window glass is at a premium.  Because of the EPA's requirements to have maximum gas mileage, the car designers have dropped the hoods and raised the rears of cars to increase aerodynamic performance, which makes figuring out where the front of your car begins and the rear of your car ends a near impossible guess.  Hence, why the added the back-up cameras so you could see what you're backing up into.  (Now, granted, I know the story about the man who sadly and tragically backed up over his son, but think how that accident might have been better avoided has the rear of his car been lower.)  You can't remove the rear headrests from the back seats in the newer Toyota Corollas, so now they immediately use up 15% or more of the visible space of the rear window.  I could be wrong, but it seems like the side mirrors are smaller too.  And last, but certainly not least, there are so many damn "bells and whistles and lights" going off from the lane assist detection to the "Infotainment System" (which is very hard to use while driving if only to change a radio station) that I believe they are designing in ever more ways to become distracted drivers.  The 2019 Corolla allows for 36 pre-set FM and AM stations.  Who the heck listens to more than a few FM or AM stations while driving, even if you drive long distances between cities and different radio stations?  Oh, and one more thing that just occurred to me.  The size of these cars keeps increasing though they keep managing to make the cars more fuel efficient.  I used to drive a 1985 Camry that was about as big as my 1998 Corolla.  The new 2020 Corollas are about as big as the earlier 2000's Camry's now.  Seriously, do we need such bigger cars even if they are making them more fuel efficient?

Long story short, I miss my Dad's 1964 Dodge Dart and my 1998 Toyota Corolla.  My Dad's Dart was incredibly easy to fix.  And both cars were easy to drive, easy to see around in, got you from point A to B without much fanfare, and cost very little to maintain and drove drove for hundreds of thousands of miles.﻿

author: Rob Beard

text:
You know, you're really fucking stupid.. First of all, augmented engine noise exists because modern cars are so much better insulated than they used to be, and combined with muted turbo engines you just wouldn't be able to hear any noise at all which is a big part of the sensation of driving a car. Especially with a manual transmission it is vital to have.


Secondly, "stuck on screens are so ugly and bad and engineers are just lazy" no you know what, fuck you. The reason they do it is to move the screen as far up into the driver's field of view as possible, and it works awesome and is a lot safer. When manufacturers mould the dash around the screen, everything becomes a lot more bulky than necessary. By not doing that it improves forward visibility and makes you feel less encapsulated in the car. I love it on my car, think it looks great.


Third, just because you're an old fart who doesn't understand technology doesn't mean it's all crap. The 3rd gen Ford Focus did not rely on it's infotainment for operating functions in the car, and the result was that the dash was covered in buttons, which looks ugly and is a pain to use. My new 4th gen Focus has moved over half of the buttons of the old car into the Sync 3 system. It's not as excellent as VW's or Mercedes new systems, but it is a hell of a lot better than the old Focus. The entire dashboard is cleaned up as a result, and everything looks and works 10 times better.


Fourth, you decide the size of wheels you want on your own car you dipshit. Having a car that looks good is important though, if not I'd just buy some crappy Hyundai on 16's and call it a day. My Focus on 18's in Active trim looks awesome, so pleased with it. So it costs a bit more, but it's worth it. And I have adaptive dampers so the ride is smooth as silk.


Just because you don't like that car manufacturers aren't stuck in the 80's where you are doesn't mean what they're doing is stupid. Stop acting like you're some kind of authority on this, it's ridiculous how you believe you know better than a multi billion dollar corporation. I love my Ford Focus, and apart from the door handles it is a "culprit" of every single point on your list. And thank god for that, it's better than it's predecessor in every single manner because of it. Thank you.﻿

author: NYGlockinator13

text:
I strongly DISAGREE about the ELEVATED INFOTAINMENT SCREENS. I have had cars with the screens lower, the screens  incorporated into the center stack, and the screens elevated.
The ELEVATED POSITION IS BETTER:
1.) They are up near eye level, so your eyes wander off the road less.
2.) They are up where they are easier to INTERACT WITH...especially the newer TOUCHSCREENS.
3.) They are easier to service and repair.
...the KEY is to buy cars with GOOD, FAST TOUCHSCREENS (e.g. BMW) that are LINKED with EASY-TO-USE CONSOLE-MOUNTED CONTROL KNOBS...so you DON'T HAVE TO TAKE YOUR EYES OFF THE ROAD TO USE.
fyi, the silly "touchpad" controls (e.g. Lexus) are a bust, fussy and imprecise.﻿

author: William Eudy

text: THANKS for the bit on the tires. You mentioned the suspension and dampeners.  To add to that, tires ARE a vital part of the suspension system. Well, they used to be. Short tire heights basically remove much of that "suspension" element from the tire, which means all that retuned stuff, has to pick up the slack from the road (and those cough rims don't have anything helping them either). Vibrations and bumps have to go somewhere...which leads to suspension components rattling more, and wearing out sooner. It's also a marketing thing. Yeah, they have that "look" thing going on, and yet, tire dealers love it. They wear out SO much faster (average of 10-20K miles, versus 40-80K of the taller tires), it guarantees repeat business for a more expensive tire that pretty much costs the same to manufacture as the older ones. And those damaged rims... Brilliant.﻿

text: Well, I am an old codger going to be 80 in a few weeks. I was the first among my friends and foes to throw away Carbon Leads and installed solid copper wires. The other part is not giving the choice of not having them. I don't like Modern Ignition Keys loaded with a lot of unnecessary operations. I remember having two keys:: door and boot / trunk. The big problem with Electronics and Microprocessors is that manufacturers penny pinch and use the cheapest, resulting in short circuits causing big damage. The other big problem is with spare parts especially circuit boards and digital displays, both being very sensitive to Voltage, Heat, Damp and Dust. Due to heavy onslaught of Electronics, repairs cannot be done at ordinary garages. Dealers are blood sucking leeches charging huge sums for doing no work. Another is filling tryes with Nitrogen and charging extra. Ironically the Air we breathe consists of 79% Nitrogen, 29% Oxygen and 1% others. Most dwellers of Industrialized Countries are forced to live at distances need driving due to very expensive and poor public transport systems. Governments, Car and its accessories manufacturers, dealers, garages, insurance companies and financiers fleece the Old Joe.﻿

author: HawkeyeSTiGuy

text:
Miscellaneous comments from someone from  Paraguay ( we have all tiers) 

i like technology in cars applied only to the engine mechanics and vehicle handling and yet i dislike  over complication in comfort features  , i like to understand stuff without investing my life in it .

Is there any modern car users that use ALL the tech comfy features in their car ? 

I daily  drive an ethanol  4 cylinder 8 valve ported injection car ( no quantic science here )  with a basic cloth interior, power windows and an aftermarket radio.  AC has a digital display but the controls are  all steel cable driven , no CAN BUS and sh*t .  It has around 9 years and 180.000 Km  I have never had an unexpected failure and don't believe I will. 

I've driven modern cars and even have access to drive a more modern vehicle , but i don' t like the feeling of not being in control within safety in addition to the visual pollution of features totally useless to me . 

You are supposed to drive , not to " infortain" yourself, you have other devices for that and with better quality  , like myself . hating  browsing the web  on a phone ( no matter the specs) , i prefer using a computer. 

Have the songs you like playing on a good sound system and your  (well serviced) car will be the best . (with a decent level of trim of course  )﻿

author: razziade

text: 20" rims on cars should not exist. My 2011 Ford SHO had 19" rims and I never damaged one. I live in Edmonton which has over 450,000 pothole repairs every year. My 2015 SHO came with 20" rims. I have bent or split 5 rims from potholes and uneven manholes in 4 years each costing $1200 to replace. I bought a C6 Corvette used that has 20" rims on the rear. I have only driven the car 6000 km and already bent a rim from a speed bump that I did not go over very hard. Large rims require 45 series tires or even lower profile side walls. 45 series tires are not enough protection to absorb bumps or potholes.﻿

text: The fake engine noise is just stupid, that practice needs to die. The one I really hate though is the practice of using 4 cylinder turbo to make the power that a bigger 4 cylinder or a V6 made in the past. Most of these 4 cylinder turbo engines will never be as reliable as a bigger 4 cylinder or a V6. The fuel economy savings that some people want to claim is the reason for the small 4 cylinder turbo just don't pan out because what happens is people rev on it more to get the power and so it spends more time under heavy acceleration and at higher RPM which it turn actually causes the car to use more gas. I would ask car manufacturers to please bring back the more reliable V6 in place of the turbo 4 in most vehichles where a V6 has been replaced with a turbo 4.﻿

author: Nal Dawson

text:
According to your video, I've recognized that you have had missed some of the reasons of things...
Engine noise: I also hate created engine noises inside, but outside an electric vehicle it makes sense. People on street are more able to recognize the incoming vehicle, even though e-cars are silent.
Turbos: In europe car companies use turbos nearly in every motor, because of the emission requirements. They are using 1.0, 1.6 liter engines, and they have to boost it, because it can't power efficiently an SUV.
Big wheels, tiny windows: Now that's design. To make a car more aggressive, dynamic, sporty looking, designers are using bigger wheels/wheelbases, and a higher centerline. This is why their products look like this.﻿

text:
i sawped my wheels and tires on my project car to get more grip out of it, i went from 185 65 R15 to 225 35 r18. but i am in the making of swapping out the entire suspension setup to coil overs front and i am concidering to build push rods but it will probably just be the rear end from a BMW that i am going to build in the rear of my volvo cause it is way simpler to get right and get good handling.


great video tho, i don't agree with the 'stuck on screen'. i think it looks really simple and nice when the screen is just there with no fancy molding around it. it is personal pereferences tho and something i like doesn't you have to like
I also don't agree with the turbo everything problem you talk about, i love turbo engines due to the ketchup effect where you squeeze the throttle and nothing happens until 3500 rpm. just love it. but the turbo is a good thing when it is well implemented in normal every day cars too, you can have a smaller engine which has better fuel economy than a bigger one with the same amount of horse power but when you want or need the power is it there. there are some cars as you mentioned that have turbo issues, Saab is another one. my dad had a Saab 95 where the compressor blades detached from the shaft and pretty much killed that car on the spot, repairable but it was a costly repair. but on the other hand is there the volvo 940 turbo, i own 2 and they are stupid reliable and both of my cars have around 300 000 km on them with no sign of them getting worn.﻿

author: orlan dodobird

text: The worst trend I am seeing is the omitting of spare tires. My Mercedes doesn't have a spare tire and they tell me it has a run flat tire. Well that is great if you just get a leak or in Germany where they have a service station every 2 km but here in North America (Canada specifically) there are a lot of long stretches with no towns or service stations so if you bend your rim or blow out your tire somewhere on the Alaska Hwy or some other place where the sign next service 200 km fill up now you are screwed. But going back to the run-flat tire,  where do you get it fixed in some small town or someplace where they don't carry run-flat tires. I know it is just not Mercedes but a lot of car manufacturers are doing this but many other car makers, BMW, Chev, Audi, etc. How many people check to see if there is a spare tire when you are buying a new car? I bet most people just assume that there is a spare in the back somewhere. I believe spares are a safety issue and should be mandatory in cars but it looks like the manufacturers are trying to cheap out by eliminating something that does not get used very often and it saves weight, but do you think that you are paying any less for care because there is no spare?﻿

author: Chump Johnson

text:
You fail to properly place blame for a few of these.  Government CAFE mandates have caused the influx of I-4 turbos vs. V6 engines.  On the EPA laboratory cycle, most turbos never spool up and you get a nice EPA CITY/HWY number.  In the real world, people pass, accelerate at intersections and dart through traffic. The turbo then gives the customer the power they want, but the real-world mileage ends up being the same as a V6.   Rear-view cameras were mandated once they seemed like a good idea....problem is now, the manufacturers can build up the back of a car for looks, and no longer worry if someone can see out of the back.  

The screens being high is a GOOD thing.  Unless you want a mound on your dashboard, it probably is the only good way to get peoples eye level up by the road.  My Jeep had a nice 8 inch screen but you had to look down off the road to use it.   My new Audi has the iPad fused on the dash.  Less eye drop is safer.   

Agree 100% on fake stuff, that is completely 100% the fault of the manufacturers.  Playing devils advocate on the fake engine sounds, some makes sell the same car to two different clientele's.  Take a BMW 3 or an Audi A4.   One customer is a well-off 60 something who wants a luxury car that is a quiet competent cruiser, the other customer is a well-to-do 20 something that wants to use the car for a fun performance drive.﻿

text: You quite clearly no nothing about cars beyond aesthetic. Turbos are nessisary to reduce emissions especially in european cars. Legislation dictate carbon, co2 and NOx emission levels and a turbo delivers more air to mix with direct injected fuel to ensure more fuel is cleanly burnt and thus reduce soot and co2 coming out the exhaust. It also allows cars to use smaller engines with the same performance. A smaller engine means better fuel economy as cars can be lower and more aerodynamic, wiegh less and generally use less fuel.﻿

author: Howell Ruehl

text:
I wish someone with an engineering background would make these kind of videos.... some are valid complaints, e.g. car sounds, plastic chrome, fake vents, turbo everything, fake marketing. But the popping doorhandles (streamline), Big rims (also fuel economy/streamline->performance), screens (cheap to manufacture and give a lot of info and fewer buttons to break and less weight) What do i hear you say: 'buttons rarely break nowadays'  true, same with doorhandles, it aint electronics from the 80's and 90's on Italian on French cars. I'm not a big button pusher, I rarely push a button in my car (audio is on the steering wheel, climate is automatic, rain/light= automatic, I sometimes push the seat warmer I might do that 5 times a year, the only frequent used button is the window defogger) So I rather have a screen with useful information than a wide range of buttons cluttering up my dash.  People calling the screens dangerous are just complete retards, do some research.
Screens are actually safer as it gives the important information within eyesight and how is a radio with small buttons safer? Some manufactures use to many screens or to big like some did too many buttons . 
Some cars like the bmw i3 have a really big rims size (19 inch,  for the car size) and very thin tires (155,  /70= thin wall), all in the name of economy (essentially streamline too, because they are very narrow but still big in size so they have the same road contact area as a thicker 16 inch 'normal tire', but with less frontal area, maintaining performance also offering a smoother ride. The big wheel sizes are actually pretty smart).﻿

author: Keith Balante

text:
As far as marketing, which is near and dear to my heart....I find that 99.999% of the jackasses who claim they aren't affected by marketing are absolutely influenced by it.  They may not be aware of it, and they may talk a great game about all the buzzwords and claims, but at the end of the day it influences their decision-making.  

Millions of companies around the world continue to use shitty buzzwords that don't really differentiate them from the competition. They do it because it still works. Human beings are fucking irrational dumbasses who like to tell themselves that they're neither irrational, nor a dumbass.  

Ages ago, before I was involved in marketing, I laughed at JC Penny's constant stream of "sales"....a new one seemingly every week. Retailers such as Harbor Freight use the same tactic. I questioned why anyone would ever buy JC Penny products at a regular price when they could just wait for a sale. And I reasoned that the sales were a fucking stupid idea and that JC Penny should just permanently lower all of its prices to the "sale" price. After all, I reasoned, if people only wait for sale prices anyway, then they ought to be thrilled that everything is now everyday low priced.  

Well, around a decade ago, the new CEO Ron Johnson, did exactly that. He got rid of the sales and moved to everyday low prices. Logical, right? Now you could buy their products at the lower prices any time you like. Well, counterintuitively, it was one of the strategies that permanently fucked JC Penny so deeply that the company never recovered. Why?  Because irrational fucking dickhead human beings love the feeling they get when scoring a sale...even if the fucking sale occurs practically every fucking week anyway. 

So when you tell yourself you're not affected by fucking buzzwords and embellished marketing claims, you're fucking lying to yourself.  I know that for a fact. Not only because I'm one of the people creating the ads that people claim to hate (yet they buy shit anyway), but because I recognize that I'm affected by them to, even as a fucking knowledgeable expert in the field.﻿

In fact, bang for your buck, manufacturer's could optimize injectors, ignition systems, exhaust, blocks, etc. In some cases the turbos add thousands in complexity and costs while adding no more than a couple dozen horses to the wheel hp.I'm convinced it's more a marketing appeal to dickheads who like anything with the term "turbo" on it.﻿

author: Average Joe

text:
KEYLESS SYSTEMS! That's my big peeve. I was ready to buy a Golf GTI but walked out of the store because they had the keyless system as a standard, non-deselectable option. As is well known by now, keyless systems are both impractical and make the cars easier to steal.

A thing on the list I disagree with is the turbocharging. Maybe they have more problems in America, but here in Europe they actually work very well, and they have enabled manufacturers to build smaller, more energy efficient engines while still retaining the power output of 100-140hp. Look for instance at the Ford 1.0L engine, smaller than an A4 piece of paper, yet producing 120hp easily. The reason American car companies went bust is that they didn't think of this kind of thing - everything had to be a huge V8.﻿

text: Not that I am an expert in cars, but I think turbo charged systems first of all add to the price of the car because the rest of the engine components have to be built around it. author: Scott Trimble

text: It's really only overcomplicated to someone that doesn't understand it. In that case they shouldn't be under the hood anyways. Unfortunately for progress to take place we need to do things that go outside of people's comfort zones. We have to move past the days of the pushrod 2v V8 in order to increase fuel mileage and power. Now you can have a v6 that makes double the power that's half the size of a V8 and gets better milage. These new turbo motors are going to be inherently more complicated then the typical pushrod engine of yesterday. But as I said the increase of power and better mileage make the complication worth it to most. To someone like myself I can even attain much more power by doing a simple tune on one of these cars or trucks by increasing boost and modifying the fuel curve. Not saying that you are one of the people that don't get it, just bringing up this point because in my opinion for progress to happen things need to change. When things change they become complicated to many. but, the new generation of gear heads will think the current tech is simple when 50 years down the road cars are being ran with superconductors or who knows what lol﻿

author: Budz Wingren

text:
Honestly I don’t mind complexity. I love being able to control more aspects of my car. 
People need to adapt to if you don’t want complex don’t play with it. Don’t take it away from those that do.
All my cars are tweaked for me. Take those settings away I won’t buy it. Name a car guy that doesn’t want to play with everything the car has to offer. Besides if you can’t work it a car stereo how the hell do you expect them to work the car safety systems. 

For your turbo bit. Turbos are great. They add complexity. But they literally take unused waste energy and turn it into power and greatly increase economy. They are very reliable. Look at turbo diesels they go forever.
Turbos where only bad in the 80s when the V8 was the king and turbos were unreliable. This is not the case now. This is why more cars do it. It’s not “cheap” at all. Making a V6 NA is cheaper then a I4 turbo. 
In most cases the little turbo 4 will eat the v6 in economy, power, depreciation and weight.

If you know much about cars these points you made are pretty invalid.

Also I have a 5.7L built V8 and a turbo charged car and the turbo has NEVER let me down.

Don’t want power, options and features? Don’t buy an expensive car. Buy a basic one and be done. But dont spread this trash and ruin it for us all.﻿

text:
I strongly agree with most of your points.
But how some gadgets are worth it I "learned" by my beloved 2001 Celica.
A 2-DIN radio with bluetooth, DAB+ and navigation not only helps you, it makes your car look at least a bit more modern.
Also it is nice to have a seat heater, so I built one in, BUT trying to use parts it still fits within the time, the car was built.
And larger Wheels... thats where I disagree.
My winter tires are 205/45 r16. They feeling quite wobbly.
My old summer tires were 215/45 r17. They were really balanced.
And beacause the car anyway feels like having "no" suspension, I stepped it up to 225/35 r18 and it just looks great.
Where I agree on this: Things like A-Class, Mini-Cooper or SUVs don't need large rims.

author: Jack of All

text: I have a 2019 Jeep Wrangler JLU Now typically the current manufacturer is really terrible at the job of making cars lol, but they did it right this time. They avoided all the garbage stated in the video; however you can get the turbo engine if you want. I couldn’t in good conscience tell someone I have a 4 cylinder engine (turbo or not) in a Wrangler. The Uconnect entertainment system is absolutely hands down 100% useful with no junk fluff features, large spaced out icons. It does give the altitude, longitude, pitch, roll and live weather maps which wouldn’t be useful to mall crawlers but if you’re rock crawling out on the Rubicon, these features are indespensible! No blinding chrome, 8” screen is sculpted into the dash and stock models are sold with very smooth, proportionate and quiet tires, but it’s a Jeep so tires don’t stay there long lol. Squishy sidewalls and mudding don’t dance well together. Jeep always has had an awful safety rating but they aren’t made to drive on pavement much less wreck at 65 mph. 5 stars off road stock though. Jeep did it right this time by keeping it modern and perfectly simple.﻿

author: Cars fan and minivan fan Fattah

text:
I agree with most of your gripes, except the turbo complaint.
@8:25
Yes, just slapping a turbo on what was a naturally aspirated engine is very poor engineering and destined for problems. However, turbos are the future. As a reasonable commuter car, I believe the best overall compromise is a 1.8 to 2.2 liter turbo diesel with electroregenerative braking and boost. Not purely electric, but enough to capture most of the energy that would've otherwise been lost to heat dissipation. The benfi of a turbo, when done right, is to have virtually two engines in one. casual driving is economical, and power is still available when needed, and weight savings from smaller engines. Diesels are economical and torquey little bitches which is great for acceleration in the city and onto the highway, and great for reasonable commuting speeds around 80 miles per hour. Of course gasoline engines have better top end and horsepower, but for the driving I described, a small turbo diesel is far more effective and efficient. The electroregenerative aspect is optional, but would increase efficiency and acceleration, also due to great starting and low end torque inherent to DC motors. I'm not against other cars, and of course I'd love to own a Porsche Carrera GT or 9 series, I just think that with current, proven technologies, a 2 liter turbo diesel power plant is a great choice. 
I've had plenty of vehicles, and 2 very different ones stand out. I had a Fiat Spyder in the 80's and I recently had a supercharged AMG. Looking up the specs for the Spyder I discovered it only had 105 HP. It went exactly 100 mph, with 5th gear at just under yellowline, which around 5700 rpm (don't quote me). I thought is was well engineered and balanced bc it could sit there at that RPM continuous, through a whole tank of gas on the highway, not an RPM wasted, and nothing strained. Fill er up and head out again. It was a little 1.8 liter twin overhead cam carburetor engine, and although built by Fiat, it had some minor Ferrari technology in there, but nothing to really mention. It sounded great, and although it didn't knock your head back, it wasn't slow either, but it was a lot of fun to wind and shift through the gears, especially with the top down. On the other hand, the AMG's acceleration was insane, and the top speed was up there too...I hit the governor at 155 several times, and yet it was planted on the road.  However, that speed is highly unlawful. And that's the thing...I could never really push that car bc within a couple quick seconds, you've accelerated up to the triple digit 'arrest-able speed' numbers. The 'fun' is over almost as soon as it starts, and you have to keep a watchful eye on that speedo. Inadvertently cruising up to 90+ is just too easy. The modestly powered 5 speed manual convertible gave me time to enjoy the wind out and shifts. 
Anyway, most commuter traffic driving is about efficient acceleration and cruising up to around 80 mph, and the 2 liter TD easily beats gas powered cars, IMHO. I think they will become very popular in the US soon.﻿

author: dispatchnig vomitory

text: You totally missed the one new trend that I totally hate and is very dangerous...extremely bright headlights.  These LED and/or xenon monstrosities totally blind the other drivers.  All it takes is a small hill crest or misadjusted headlights or someone with their high beams on and I literally can not see the road anymore.  The new Jeep Wrangler is one of the worst because the lights are so high to begin with.  I know the old-style headlights are out of vogue with millennials and don't quite light up the street for drivers, but it is worth blinding everyone else?  Maybe those driving in SUVs and trucks don't notice it because they sit higher, but those of us who choose to drive in more efficient, easier-to-park cars are bearing the brunt of it.  Oh, and brake lights that flash when the brake is originally applied...even it is only lightly applied.  Why attract my attention away from everything else (pedestrians, motorcycles, etc.) just because you are applying your brake?  I see it mostly on ambulances. And finally, LED brake lights that flicker.  Yes, I can see the flickering.  They do this to dim the light because regular LEDs don't dim...they are either on or off.  If you are going to use a duty cycle to "lower" the light, please do it at a frequency that I can't see.  It is really noticeable when you dart your eyes...the tail lights look like strobe lights.  If you never noticed this, you're lucky.  Cadillacs are the worst.﻿

author: Yuri Pershin

text: Remote keys and touchless car keys. A constant source of issues and ridiculous costs. After three years: batteries are empty, without any warning! Replacement at car dealer: 60,- EUR!! At home: 50cent. An extra key: 300 EUR. I don't want to even know what replacing a lost key cost, including recoding cost. And for three times our Mazda did not get started. It was still connected to the other key or couldn't decode the key signal. And certainly security is a joke. Another wonderful invention: yearly or 10.000km oil replacement for fully synthetic oil. At Mazda the original oil alone cost > 100 EUR. Plus the service charge - another 50,- EUR at the dealer. Thank god there are alternative on the free market. A frequent driver would need to change the oil every two month. For car multimedia there is a simply solution. Connect smartphone via Bluetooth and use smartphone. Done. Same for navigation. The only navigation that really works is Google maps. All in car navigation systems have terrible search functions, maps are outdated, real time traffic density is unavailable and also the display of the route is usually bad.﻿

text: My GTI got sooo much better when I unplugged the Soundaktor (fake engine noise machine) after a month. Unlike other companies that use the car's speakers, VW actually makes a little device that sits behind the dash and vibrates the windshield to make the fake engine noise. It interferes with bluetooth phone calls, drones on the highway (who wants a noisier car on a road trip?), was definitely making me upshift too early a lot of the time since it made the engine sound like it was working harder than it actually was, and for some dumb reason could only be turned down but not all the way off. Also, the GTI has a sweet little engine that sounds totally fine. It was such a pleasure to go for a drive and actually hear it for the first time.﻿

author: chomihai

text:
1 Power steering over-powered.  When the power assisted steering is so powerful that the driver gets no physical feedback through the steering wheel.
2 Building for the race track.  There are a bunch of models that have been developed on race tracks rather than roads in recent years.  This almost always ends up with a car that is terrible on UK roads.
3 Over-complicated electronics.  While I like my creature comforts I would like to be able to either service my car myself or have the confidence to go down to my local garage and find someone who can do it for me without worrying about wether they have that brands service laptop.
4 Non modular designs.  There are so many systems in modern cars that once they go down (air conditioning being a prime example) it is not worth the money to get them fixed becaus you would practically need to dismantle the whole vehicle.  Even changing a headlight bulb can involve taking the front bumper and other equipment off several models I have come upon.﻿

text: “Maybe Jaguar and Land Rover should put money into making their cars more reliable instead of gimmicks.” Excellent statement. I suspect though that poor reliability is part of the JLR look and feel, and designed in. Oversized wheels: yup, pay a fortune and you get a hard ride, and very expensive to replace tyres. author: sportsfan ivosevic

text:
I have to disagree with a few of those.
First of all, turbos.
They don't make sense in the US where you could buy the cheapest N/A base model of any car, slap 10 turbos on it and still be street legal. Or swap it with a 10L engine that's poking out the hood and, again, still be street legal.
But in the rest of the world swapping an engine is expensive and exhausting, and not because you buy a high quality engine that needs a lot of modifications done to the car in order to fit, but because of all the trouble you have to go through to actually use that engine legally and also the taxes are basically skyrocketting.
It's way better to have a turbo engine and the possibility to remap the engine and squeeze even more HP out of it.
The 150HP diesel Golf 4 can go very well up to 220HP with only an ECU remap. And that without any other hardware mod (besides a racing-spec DPF).

Infotainment systems.
They would be really good if they were made properly.
And by that i mean to be using Android and Android only.
No more laggy proprietary OSs and no more highly outdated Windows CE.
A friend has an Android tablet instead of a radio in his Golf 4.
It's very useful, it's up to date and it can connect to the OBD2 port to display horsepower, torque, speed, etc., basically a more advanced dashboard.
Also, you can split screen Waze and Spotify, something you simply cannot do on an OEM infotainment.
Plus, you can use your preferred brand of rear view cameras.

Edit: My personal problem with cars nowadays is how automated they are, but how simple things were automated the wrong way.
Parking brakes, start&stop, assists literally everywhere, etc.
You can't even roll down your windows manually anymore.
Also the doors who get stuck in 3 pre-defined positions and you literally have to fight the door to keep it from hitting you or hitting the car next to you.
Also the visibility decreased over the years.﻿

text: Agree with most of these but the ones regarding the infotainment, although I do agree the lack of update/support is concerning. What's wrong with packing more into the screen? One of the examples you used was an equalizer built-in. That's fucking awesome. Not just that, but all the other "extra" features. *They're only a net positive*. All the basic features that you're making a case for to go back to the "good old days", they're still there, and I'm willing to bet 99% of the time they're within one screen from the home screen. If you personally don't need any of the extra features, then that's fine, but making a case that it's too complex is such a older generation mentality. "I don't get it and I don't need it, therefore it's unnecessary, we didn't need it before so why do we now". And for those who are about to say "they're so unnecessary", well then by that logic so is everything else we have in modern cars, like radio. Most of these features aren't even meant to be adjusted by the driver while driving, and all the necessary ones (like volume and temperature control) are usually on the home screen anyway.﻿

author: george w kush

text:
The worst trend in modern technology is that devices are no longer our tools, but we become rather a tool of the devices. They think for us instead of helping us to think. They make life more comfortable but at the same time we cannot use that added spare time wisely anyway, being a lazy biological creature as we are. And without them we cannot do anything since we enslave us to our tools. Even more in future. And the worst thing is that most people don't even understand how these technologies do work thus being even more vulnerable to the disadvantages I mentioned. Also, we become more pure users of devices but not the owners. The ownership is still with the manufacturers and they define what we are allowed or not allowed to do with their devices. Some people say that tablets and smartphones will make clobby computers obsolete. Try programming on an iPad then. No way to compile code in an arbitrary programming language and execute the program. You are not allowed to do so and that's not because the device wouldn't be able to do that.

For cars particularly I don't like the shift to touch screens. I don't like touch screens in computers and mobile devices neither. With haptic feedback I can type blindly, I can turn on the car's heater or light. My brains knows where to reach and how far I have to turn. But with a touch screen I will have to look away from the traffic only to go through the menu to do the simple task. Beside that I am a fan of knobs and "complexity". I don't like that clinic tidiness of technology where all the magic disappears behind an empty facade. No Apple, technology is not on it's best when it simply disappears. I am a power user, not a dumb guy who needs a limited, foolproof system that I must fight with only to make it do what I want and not what I was limited to do.﻿

author: Bradley Conrad

text:
Maybe just a pet peeve of mine, but my wife is 5'2" tall and I'm 6'1".  I can't fit in the vehicle with the seat all the way forward, so I have to stand outside the car, holding the damn button for like 20 seconds to slowly, ever so slowly, move the drivers seat back. Either make it faster or include a manual lever for coarse adjustment and just use the electric for fine adjustment of the seat position.

Does the "feature" on pretty much all cars these days that you have to push the unlock button on the key fob twice to unlock all of the doors really provide a measure of safety?  The proximity sensor (RFID?) already unlocks the driver and passenger side doors so where is the safety issue?  But when my hands are full and I would like to throw my stuff (usually laptop, etc) in the back seat, I have to find the fob and hit the button a couple of times to unlock the back doors.  On both my Honda and Toyota, you can program just about every other aspect of the locking system from what speed it locks the doors, to whether it unlocks when you put it in P or turn off the key, etc. but you can't defeat this "personal safety" feature that as far as I can tell provides no personal safety.

Smart keys that aren't very smart.    We were skiing up in Jackson Hole WY last week and had a rented Nissan Rogue.  It was -27C, so I went out to warm up the car and scrape the windows.   I started the car, grabbed the scraper, got out, closed the door and heard the dreaded click of the doors all locking.  So I was stuck for over an hour with the car running, the key inside and the doors all locked.  Smart keys are not supposed to do that.﻿

author: Richie Mandina

text:
@Richie Mandina It has nothing to do with aerodynamics, having larger windows doesn't impact that unless you change the shape of the cabin.
It's because modern safety regulations require a cars fortified impact zone meet a certain height, and that pillars be of a certain strength (achieved with thicker posts) for increased safety in a rollover. Also only a certain percentage of a cars surface area is allowed to be glass. This is all to prevent people from getting crushed in a rollover and having less of their skin be shredded by flying glass.﻿
author: Sunny Afternoon

text: @Sunny Afternoon I mean, you may be mostly right about all that, but how could you believe that aerodynamics has nothing to do with it at all? Cabin shape clearly has a lot to do with aerodynamics. That's why you don't see many SUV's sitting up high, with steep windshields like they used to have. Now they have these huge windshields that are nearly horizontal, and ugly cabins and dashboards that are designed to accommodate this new shape. And if you're looking to cut through the air easier, wouldn't that obviously include making the cabins more squat, consequently reducing the space for windows? I'm not saying it's not about safety, but I think it's silly to assume it's not affected in the least by the pursuit of more aerodynamic vehicles for higher MPG's﻿
author: Richie Mandina

text: @Richie Mandina Fair point. What I meant was rather that cars in the past got around the visibility issues while maintaining excellent aerodynamics because they were able to use more glass and thinner pillars. They can't do that anymore, so when they had to meet both safety and efficiency standards, visibility is what they sacrificed. I guess it's a combination of both, sorry if I seemed like a jackass or something.﻿
author: Sunny Afternoon

text: @Sunny Afternoon all good my friend. And no you didn't sound like a jackass. Conversations are always a bit more awkward and confusing when written out﻿

author: Michael Long

text:
I'll admit I used to think that the Stuck On Screen was simply being lazy in that they didn't want to remold the dashboard.  While I'm relatively certain that was the origin of doing it that way, I'm actually growing more towards liking that system.  I would say it goes right along with the too much tech issue.  System settings for the radio, nav, environment systems buried in a touch screen menu system get out of hand.

But the problem multiplies when you need a bigger screen to show more information/controls and remove physical buttons for the A/C or radio controls.  What happens with non standardized tech and a bigger screen?  The air vents get pushed around.  With a big screen in the middle, the air vents often get pushed to the side and are blowing on your hands instead of into the environment of the vehicle.  Having a Stuck On Screen means that historically standard physical controls, and air vents remain where they should.  As a person who works in construction, I understand the need for how any HVAC system needs air flow to balance an interior environment in a home or office building.

Stuck On Screens are not near as attractive as dash mounted infotainment screens, but they usually allow the rest of the system to be more user friendly and functional.﻿

author: closeaus88

text:
It's not a new trend, and it goes off the overcomplication, but a lack of standardization.
Other than the turn signal and the placement of the wheel and pedals, nothing is standardized. Sometimes the light controls are on the turn signal lever, sometimes it's on the dash, sometimes it's on the driver's side mini-dash. Different cars from the same manufacturer have the gas tank on different sides of the car. The gas and hood release latches can be on the floor, in the dash, under the dash, or the car might not need one (usually with the gas, I haven't seen a modern car without a hood release latch somewhere inside).﻿

text: The reason why they put turbos on everything is because turbocharged engines sport excellent MPG statistics in paper. Small displacement turbo engines are specifically designed to pass official emission tests with top honors, where they press the throttle gently. Problem is, due to turbo lag, nobody ever presses the throttle gently on a turbo engine, everybody floors the throttle instead.﻿

author: MUHAMMAD YASIR KHANZADA

text:
Read some of the comments... and I gotta say, good job video maker for actually choosing items that made sense as to why they're useless/whatever... As for what I'm reading in alot of the comments... its just alot of personal taste and opinions... Like the people who constantly say "A truck is for work, not for someone to drive" when... yea, its a Truck. Its meant to be DRIVEN... It can be used to haul, and to toe, but its main purpose is to be DRIVEN... it is a MOTOR VEHICLE... If you have the 100k to spend on a tricked out truck, then more power to ya. Just don't be an idiot with it. If you use it to haul things or toe things/for work, then again, more power to ya. You can tow just as much with a TDI Jetta as you would with most trucks that people tend to buy. So why not label that as a 'work vehicle to'? Just doesn't make sense. Let people drive what they want to drive. Its an aesthetic choice. You want something big and powerful looking that can also do some work if ya want to, then you get a truck. If you don't care much about having that 'big powerful' look, you get a car. Simple as that. 

Then I see people complaining about the huge touch screens. Sure, sometimes they're garbage. But you know why they're garbage? Its the processor built into the car. Not the screen. Most of those screens would actually be SUPER AMAZING if they didn't take 50 minutes to go from one screen to the next. And that's allllll thanks to the stupid slow processors in them. Look out for 2019, as Samsung is releasing processors for cars that are just as powerful as their smart phones... So imagine having a display in the car that DOESN'T lag and stutter every time you need to use it!

And finally as a remark to the actual video... Honestly, I'd love to see a car that had zero windows, and instead had super amazingly powerful cameras and displays.... You could completely change how the car looks, and redesign the occupant placement... You could make the thing SUPER INSANELY SAFE.... 60mph crashes with ZERO injuries even.... Ontop of that, these cameras could have IR cameras, allowing you to see perfectly clear in the dark without being blinded by other drivers or blinding other drivers yourself. And because it would be using IR, it then could also detect thermal instances. Aka, you could see a deer or animal on the side of the road MILES (literally) ahead of you! It'd also make autonomous driving even better and safer... I can not see a single downside to such a thing other than "oh well what if a camera breaks? what if the screen breaks? what if the power goes off?" in which i'd say "What if your windshield shatters? What if your windshield shatters? What if your headlights go out?" There isn't anything that wouldn't have an equivalent situation with a Windshield.... If it shatters, you can't see out of it... if you push it away, now you cant' see because of the wind/glass shards destroying your eyes. If your headlight goes out, welp you can't see.﻿

text: Something I have been noticing is how the settings of airbags have changed. In the past, they would deploy only in serious accidents, where the car was probably totaled anyway. Nowadays a simple fender bender means that several airbags will pop, ruining the dashboard and the sides of the interior. I am appalled at seeing cars with easily and cheaply repairable broken headlights and grill, but an interior looking as if a naughty dog was locked in there for a day, courtesy of the airbags.﻿

text: Great video.  I agree.  Edmunds gave my Mitsubishi Outland Sport a lackluster review. You cannot put a 10 year 100 thousand mile warranty on the drive train, a 7 year 70 thousand mile warranty on rust through or a 6 year 50 thousand bumper to bumper warranty on a car that is unreliable. text: I’d say the biggest issue with the current trend is DI: direct injection. The design is fundamentally flawed. When the engine is new, it’s all good. But overtime it will build up carbon deposit on the back of the inlet valves, which leads to lower power, lower efficiency, much higher emission than non DI engine, and rough running engine as well. The maintenance cost is much higher than non DI engines. That’s why Toyota has resisted the urge to introduce DI only engines for their popular models. DI is partially the response to the ever stringent emission regulation, and marketing: a very sorry story because it actually cause more emission over the life time of the cars with DI, all things considered.﻿

author: savagegeese

text: @savagegeese I live in the Indiana and have a daily driver, just like everyone else that owns one of these vehicles. Realistically the most daily use you see out of a Jag or Range is maybe running the kids to school real quick in an F-Pace or its equivalent. No one is on the roads for hours in freezing rain in these cars. I'm not faulting you for calling it out because it's a common focus of hate in the auto industry and people loooove talking about it in forums so it's good for content. I just don't think it's ever actually been an issue for anyone and the people hating on these handles have probably never actually had them. I love them.﻿
author: J M

text: @J M so you've never had to park your car outside of work during an ice storm or a snow storm or anything like that?﻿
author: savagegeese

text: @savagegeese No because ice and snow storms never come without warning so when there's impending inclement weather I drive my handy dandy Honda Accord to work. Keep a weather app on my phone and a 20 second check of the forecast every morning dictates which car leaves the garage for work. I can almost see your point if you're referencing SUV's...but Range Rover/ Jaguar SUV's are rarely daily drivers to work. Usually the stay at home mom (or dad) gets the shiny SUV to make the necessary runs to school/ practices while the working parent takes the less shiny sedan to work. I guess the only exception is if both parents work...but a lot of jobs have parking garages like mine. My point is there is rarely anything outside of very minimal short term exposure to harsh elements for vehicles with flush handles. And ice storms are not common enough to forego a beautiful aesthetic feature.﻿
author: J M

text: What's most troubling about this point though is I've never known anyone run into this problem with flush handles for the reasons I mentioned above. I do know plenty of people that have broken or ripped off a traditional handle trying to pull open a door that's frozen shut. If anything a flush handle keeps you from breaking the door because there's nothing to grab and pull on before the car is thawed properly. Sorry for the book here, but any car that has flush handles also has remote start....so it's nice and warm and I can slide the ice right off the car by the time I get to the car in the unlikely event it sat through freezing rain. Just some food for thought. Sorry for the negative comment, I'm just sick of that complaint because it's an awesome feature with no actual negative repercussions.﻿
author: J M

text: @savagegeese And in order to be constructive instead of just a Youtube hater, my additions to this list in lieu of my beloved invisible handles would be engine idle stop that can't be turned off through the infotainment because that is a pointless and annoying feature used to project misleading EPA ratings. Or electronic parking brakes....because handbrakes are fun and if for whatever reason my brake pedal were to go out, it's nice to have a handbrake as backup.﻿
author: J M

text: @J M there's plenty of negative repercussions that you're forgetting.  the main one being if you have a dead battery or the motor that ejects the door handle is broken how do you open the door? Second when you're adding complication (motor units, electronics, ecu) namely on a vehicle like the range Rover velar which is already ridiculously complicated and expensive to repair.  Also as pictured in the video, when the door handle doesn't eject when you walk up to the car like it's supposed to so you sit there and wait for it to come out before you can open it which is absolutely the epitome a functionless design. It has zero function other than a "cool factor" namely on an SUV.   If you've ever spent time doing repairs on vehicles working with mechanics or having to deal with troubleshooting half baked software or technology you would have zero tolerance for this type of thing.  It's these types of "features" that lead to the over complication and other frustrating design choices implemented in modern cars. The motorized handles at their core do nothing to improve on functionality or reliability of a mechanical design that has been in use for over 70 years in cars.  Just because you can doesn't mean you should.﻿
author: savagegeese

text: @savagegeese The points you're making are primarily dealing with extreme outliers, not the overbearingly more common vast majority. Most, almost all, people that own these cars will never face an issue with these handles other than an unfamiliar passenger not knowing how to process what just happened. But to address your uncommon "issues": If you're walking up to the car and the handles don't come out on time, the issue is with the battery in the remote, not the handle. The point that it's more expensive to fix is redundant...it's a luxury car. They're expensive. That's kind of the point and adding a few bucks to cost of repair isn't a big deal to a buyer that 9 times out of 10 isn't going to keep it past its factory warranty anyways. Warranty repairs are free and, for the record, cover you for 5 years/ 60k miles on the Jag/ Range Rovers you mentioned. Also covers routine maintenance (thumbs up emoji). I'm sure you know the dead battery thing is a far stretch because every manufacturer has a fail safe for that. The car doesn't just become a paper weight if the battery dies lol And you speak as if the technology behind moving a bit of metal/ plastic an inch and a half is some groundbreaking piece of tech that must have been bestowed upon us by some advanced alien species. Because that's really the only difference. The tumbler and inner workings of the door latch are all the same, you're just simply moving a bit of metal and or plastic to give you something to grab onto. When compared to the rest of the tech in a luxury brand vehicle...or really any modern car...it's child's play. I feel I've made and defended my point adequately, the hatred for this feature is misguided and from a population that doesn't use it on a daily basis. I can vouch for how fantastically dank and practical they are. Cheers.﻿

author: Matt Frankman

text:
My thoughts of this video as a Software Engineer

Video should be called : old guy hates new tech.
You can't knock on electronic door handles because it's one more thing to break, then complain knobs are being removed to consolidate them into 1 screen. It's literally what you wanted in less stuff to break. 

Also,  why would you knock the screen itself? I may be a Software Engineer for a living, but spending half an hour playing around with Google assistant or even Siri, which is awful in comparison; you'll find voice commands are typically intuitive and easy to use. I'd love to see legitimate integration here " Hey google, set the temp to 73" Never have to take your eyes off the road.

Onto the security concerns:
There ARE some legitimate concerns with remote functions becoming more common, however, as far as run of the mill thieves are concerned, cars to this day still have the same software vulnerabilities they've had for over a decade. Getting into a push start car with nothing but patience and a raspberry Pi has been a thing for ten years now. This isn't rocket science, it's probably something a few nights of surfing the right forums could teach you yet we don't hear about that happening on a daily basis. If you're that concerned about tech vulnerabilities buy a pre 96 vehicle that lacks OBD II- it's your safest bet for avoiding software intrusions :)

Follow-up to Security concerns.
Why do we all get to pick and choose where to draw the line? While I agree some security issues are things to worry about, I've seen many people complain about them while keeping their prehistoric 8bit garage door opener that can be hacked with a child's toy. Not even touching on the fact that their cell phones typically have BT and Wi-Fi on. Being a security enthusiast is okay. Picking and choosing where you're comfortable with your lack of security is just bias at best and paranoia at least.﻿
author: Cody Sams

text: Why would you have to ask Google to set the temperature in YOUR car?﻿
author: SuperAaron 99

text:
@SuperAaron 99 You wouldn't "have" to. Though voice controls are a much safer way to operate a vehicle. But, IoT being what it is  today. It wouldn't take much at all, maybe a bit of IFTTT at home  to get your car to work with something like your Nest. Adjust the thermostat at your house to match your car.  Hell, to be honest I'd much rather have nests intuitive Machine learning brought in via the google platform so that your car actually learns and proactively sets the temp to your preference.

There are some fantastic software additions that can be made to cars for a great QoL improvement across the board.  I'd speculate the reason we're just now starting to see things like this enter the market is because the target consumer is trending to a younger more technologically inclined generation than it previously has.﻿
author: Cody Sams

text:
@Cody Sams  I'm a tech guy and probably is in the minority compared to most people's indifference when it comes to privacy. But I wouldn't be all that excited about Google having access to every aspect of my life to the extent of a totally unnecessary gimmick like controlling the temperature in my car which has never been a problem. Facebook gets all the attention but along with Google they have horrific records when it comes to protecting user data. I really do not need or want Google to decide which temperature my car should be at, I can think and do that for myself. Even more so, if I buy a VW I'm choosing to do business with them, why should Google, a company I didn't want anything to do with when purchasing my car be thrown in there as well?  
Some things may sound cool, but when you really think about it, they just become an unnecessary annoyance.﻿
author: SuperAaron 99

text:
@SuperAaron 99  that's something you already deal with. From your speakers to your Head Unit, sure it may be a commissioned re-badged/branded product. But Toyota aren't exactly chucking out Head units and speakers in house.

And from a real technical standpoint I'd be much happier with an OpenOS kind of thing, potentially android or Linux installed in factory HUs with more access to embedded systems and other MPU related things. That way people could have their choice of Google or Apple. Or custom stuff from home etc. Sad fact is that is way way too technical. Pre-loading it with the industry leading systems (Which for home automation right now is Alexa and Google) lets more people have a device they can understand and use.


That's just on a practicality standpoint. That's not even getting into cost. It's much much cheaper to use Google or Alexa, if not a profit considering licensing deals. Than to make custom software. And with the rate cars are going heavy in all sorts of tech I don't see this very far in the future at all.

Though, again If you're someone who is concerned about privacy and security instead, setting up a VPN with VPS  properly configured to  handle the traffic should be something that is doable.

I think you're talking to the wrong person if you believe these things turn into an annoyance. Given my field and general  priviledge my entire house is automated. A ton of custom work, but a ton of other Open source stuff too like Google.

I can lock my doors, set my temp, turn off my lights, turn the radio in the bedroom on and schedule the floors to be mopped and vacuumed while I  sleep simply by saying " Hey Google, goodnight" as I walk toward my bedroom.

This goes far beyond setting the heat in the car. Real integration would be phenomenal in motor vehicles;
I'm hungry - tells you nearest restaurants/fast food
I need to pee- finds nearest restroom
Set the temp- obvious
Call x- exists in most vehicles now
When is my next appointment- obvious
I'm home- sets off a scheduled set of tasks like I have for bedtime Where it unlocks your door, sets your thermostat as you like, turns on your TV starts your coffee pot etc etc.

There's no reason anybody shouldn't want this.﻿
author: Cody Sams

text:
I should also note, you technically have this already just with your phone being on you at all times and carplay/android auto being a thing. But still full integration to interact with MPUs in your vehicle would be great. Ask google how long it's been since you've changed your oil, or, ask it what your average MPG is. Potentially even more technical things like oil pressure and such too.

Doing these things can be done now by looking at a gauge or a sticker. But it's much much safer to keep your eyes on the road and listen for a response to your inquiry than to glance away.﻿
author: Cody Sams

text:
Simplicity is the key to reliability, complexity is the enemy of security. Intuitive UI is far more preferable to a magical sky computer that you have to pray understands what you are asking for. Especially when that software has to be updated, supported for decades, and internet connected. That's insane if what you're wanting is to adjust the AC. To a setting that feels right. Who in the heck thinks, "gee, I am a bit cold, let me ask the computer to increase the temperature to 69 degrees." No, that's nonsense. You think, "turn on the heat."

This is what happens when engineers are in charge of UX, when they don't really have a clue what people actually want, it what a human centric design is.﻿
author: Adam Smith

text: @Cody Sams I think you'd be amazed how many purple wouldn't want that, for many very good reasons.﻿
author: Adam Smith

text:
@Adam Smith  I'm sorry I'm so late with my reply! But, I can see validity in your points, however, I'm more about options and function than simple adaptivity. Why would you need to consistently ask for the temp to change if it can be set once, or paired with something similar to the Nests learning AI to figure out  what your manual settings are over time and factors to automatically set them before you can?

There are crossover issues with all aspects though, it's why UX Designers don't construct. Voice command is not only more practical for everyday people like you and I, it's also more feasible for people with disabilities, such as people who don't have functioning use of their legs giving their hands much more demanding tasks to simply drive. Reaching to turn a knob or push a selection is considerably more dangerous in such situations.﻿
author: Cody Sams

text: For me, the #1 worst trend, which predates 2018 by almost a decade, is center mounted instrument clusters.   If the speedometer and gauges aren't square in front of me, such that I have to look over to the right to see it, I not only won't buy it, I won't drive it as a rental car either.   The Toyota Yaris did this back a few years ago, and it was weird-- you look to where you expect the speedometer and gauges to be and see a blank panel, you think you are a passenger in a right-hand drive car.   They finally corrected the defect in 2013 after more than 10 years of the broken design.  I suspect the reason for it is it makes it cheaper to make both a right hand drive and left hand drive version of the car, because you only have to manufacture one dashboard design.    It's a cheap-out, and it's a huge FAIL for me.﻿

author: Trenton Pottruff

text:
Pretty good list.  I selected a few that I find particularly offensive:

Awards - Anyone who buys a car based on  awards is a fool. As you hinted, how can a car be deemed dependable after one or even two years in existence. There is simply no real data to support it. The "Initial Quality" award is also a joke. It's based on total individual reported problems within a specified period, not the severity of those issues. My Mazda CX-9  had a broken seat belt retainer clip and a recall of the front door stops to replace them with a version that better held the doors when open. My Honda CR-V experienced a bad fuel gauge sending unit and the gas cap tether broke. According to the parameters of that initial quality award, both those vehicles were rated as twice as bad as those Chevys that killed over 100 people due to ignition failures (if that was the only thing that went wrong). 
As a side note, this applies to books, also. There are many fake awards out there, but even the "legitimate" awards are selected from a very small sample of all the books available for that year and genre.

Touch Screens - These are annoying enough for phones and tablets where you are stationary and can focus on what you're doing. While driving it's a nightmare for everyone to have to shift focus onto a screen and carefully touch a specific spot to activate a function. I don't mind the display screens as long as they are integrated but they need tactile (and varied) controls, and you shouldn't have to re-enact the finale of Inception to change the radio station or turn on the lights.

A few you didn't mention:

Ultra-bright headlights. In this age of selfish and/or oblivious drivers who fail to understand the concept of courtesy, this is beyond annoying. I can no longer stand to drive at night because every time I am forced to squint through a wash of white or bluish light flooding the interior from behind or blinding me from ahead.

"Safety" Sensors - These are making drivers worse by replacing good driving habits with reliance on these gadgets. They started with those backup sensors that resulted in a rash of cases of children being run over because instead of looking, the driver expected the sensor to warn them of any obstacles. The problem is the delay. If a person is watching (even with a decent back-up camera) and sees a child run behind their car they react instantly to their visual perception. when relying on sensors, those sensors must first detect the child, determine it's an obstacle, and sound an alarm. Only then can the driver react to the sound, and only after they recognize it as the backup alarm. 
My point is illustrated by the very commercials advertising such features. Watch any "demonstration" of a safety sensor in action in an ad and the driver is depicted as being a moron who doesn't pay attention. Exactly how bad a driver must a person be to not see a parade float directly ahead? The latest one that grinds my gears is the one that won't let the doors open if it detects a passing vehicle. First, stop being lazy parents and teach your kids to look and think before they act. Second, what happens when the car won't let you out after a minor crash and it comes to rest on the train tracks, or the tanker truck with which you collided is leaking acetone, or Jason gets up even though you just ran him over?

Tap-and-release gear selectors - This may be the stupidest idea for cars in the last forty years. Anton Yelchin famously died because he thought he had pushed the selector of his Jeep into PARK when he actually put it in NEUTRAL, but thousands of other people have also had issues with those selectors which is why they were in the midst of a recall. Those people aren't stupid as some have suggested, but that's extremely unfair (Anton possessed a genius-level IQ).
The problem stemmed from them retaining the general shape and placement of the gear shift lever in spite of fundamentally changing the way the gears are selected. It takes very little time for a person to develop a muscle memory of that process whether using a floor- or column-mounted lever, meaning any automatic they drive comes with the subconscious expectation they must move the gear selector in a specific direction to a specific position to change gears, and placing a vehicle in PARK means thrusting it all the way forward or counter-clockwise. Drives don't have issues with push-button or rotary knob gear selectors because they operate in a different way, removing any confusion by requiring the driver to learn a totally new motion. I like the way some new EVs have done it, eliminating the lever and having either separate, large buttons for each drive mode or using a large selectors knob that rotates into different positions rather than being twist-and-release.﻿

author: John Iii

text:
Here's some more bad trends: 
1] Safety features that promote unsafe driving. These emergency braking, automatic cruise control,  stay-in-lane features and Tesla Autopilot are great tech, but they encourage the texters of this world to spend more time texting, and they're already doing it in cars that don't have any of these features. VW commercials for one pretty much promote not looking where you're going as normal driving.
2] Along with the fake vents, how about ridiculously large grills? Numerous cars in the 90's proved that 1930's-truck size grills aren't needed for air intake and cooling on modern cars, so why the gaping maw on so many of them in the last few years?
3] No visibility to the rear. Why the continuing trend of enormous C-pillars and small rear windows on so many vehicles? It's bad enough that people don't look where they're driving; why block the view of those who do want to look?

And boy do I agree about overly complicated screens. Besides being confusing, they're another reason for drivers invitation to not look at the road, and they're a large source of unreliability in cars when other aspects have become very reliable. 

I also agree on oversized wheels. My car has had three(!) flats due to crappy road maintenance (I live in Ohio), and I would have avoided at least two of them with normal sized tires. But if you look at blue-sky concept drawings recently, many of them have even larger wheels and essentially no tires at all. 

https://www.google.com/search?q=concept+car+drawing&lr=&hl=en&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjk9O6yvr_fAhVJ44MKHfv0BScQ_AUIDigB&biw=1920&bih=966﻿
