author: roadwarrior280

text: Hey, right with you man. I was a car writer for 20-some years with a consumer-oriented magazine and web site that had around 5 million subscribers. I'll share pet peeves that endless railing and raving on my part failed to change the world. Coupe styling. No one buys a coupe but everyone wants one apparently because every damn sedan and most SUVs have a sloping roof and shortened rear window that inhibits the view aft.e.g. Chevy Impala.  Full-size pickups: we're the only country in the world that insists on them. If you're not in the trades or a farmer/rancher you don't need one. Sadly, compact pickups don't sell and get almost as crappy fuel economy. Unified controls like BMW iDrive and that flat mushroom Toyota uses. Acts like a mouse, supposedly appealing to Gen X, Y, and younger, who haven't used a mouse in years.Big alloy wheels. As you say, unnecessary, costly, damage-prone, and degrades the ride. Stylized headlights. Cat's eye headlights simply cannot illuminate as well as bigger rounder lamps. Turbo: ok in the free-horsepower sense but added complication and often are optimized for premium fuel, so where is the saving? No spare tire: WTF? You rip a sidewall and you're done. Suppose you're out of reach of "roadside assistance?" Myself, I do like touch screens, fingerprint magnet though they be. And I love having a backup camera and if you ever get a 360 degree cam, you'll never let it go. Also I like seat heaters, and steering wheel heaters.﻿

text: For decades now, manufacturers have fitted more and more complex headlamps and tail lamps. These are the first and often only part to suffer in a traffic shunt and now they are fiercely expensive - to the extent of incurring an insurance write-off on an otherwise perfect, elderly car. When I started driving in the 60's, all headlamps were round and, in fact mostly interchangeable and rear lights were small and cheap. Cars for night-time competition still have round lights so there is no case for saying there have been improvements due to shape. I have a classic sports car. The lights are still available, brand new, for $20-30 each. The lights for my small German estate car would cost twenty times as much. The classic is beautiful and admired, the estate is anonymous and ugly.﻿

author: PR M5

text:
No fake chrome/black on my car's interior.  Real knobs or simple rocker buttons for all radio and HVAC controls.  Radio  volume and scan controls built into the steering wheel.  No need to take your eyes from the road.  And, this old supercharged Regal is a sleeper; I've trounced more than one 20 something who thought he knew what he had and that old man couldn't own a fast car.  Classic wedge lines, at 20 years old, still looks great. 

My recent ex-fiance's Honda CRV had the backup camera.  I have to admit, it makes sense, and I missed it when she left.  But it's simple and does not require driver interaction. 

Overall, a good video.  I'm constantly amazed by what is made, not just cars, and what people buy.  I suggest, ask yourself this question: "Will my life be better with this?"  Answered honestly, it is almost always "No."

I probably have another ten years of driving left.  I expect my Regal GS to go for the long haul.﻿
author: Paul Verizzo

text: About 3 years ago I got so disgusted with the cost of car repairs that I bought a really nice 1979 Thunderbird. The original paint is still nice and so is the interior. Everything still works on this car, and I mean everything. Yes it’s a little slow, and a little big but I can see out of this car so well. I love the room inside and the fact that the dash is not cluttered and everything is manually operated. No real distractions. I learned to not get in a hurry in this car and noticed how much my stress level went down while driving.It doesn’t have the all the electronics that are broken or out of date in a few years. I can repair most of this car myself and the parts are cheap. If it goes in for repair, it is still cheap. I would like electronic fuel injection, but the carb was still one you can tune yourself. And yes it gets only 16 mpg combined, but the cost of repair and parts more than offsets that.  I go everywhere anyone else does. Where will all these new vehicles be in about 40 years and who would want one. If an automaker would come out with a vehicle that went back to the basics and of easy repair, they would sell like hot cakes. I know that new vehicles have to have all these safety devices, easy to replace airbag assemblies would be great. When I look at the inside of the newest vehicles out, looks like the cockpit of a fighter jet. Test drive a well kept older car and see what you have been missing. A whole lot of headache. We have to work so many hours so we can have all this technology and convenience. But we never have time to enjoy them. It’s just a vicious circle.﻿

These 2 start every time and run like new, don't burn oil, both have AC and heat, their interiors are mostly simple minded, and they are meant to be driven and enjoyed that way!  Hipsters will be messing with their stupid touch screen, carbon fouled directed injected 4 cylinders that burn oil and sound like fans, droning CVT transmissions, horrible dealer services, and massive monthly payments for years. The only things I like about new cars are cooled seats, and phone pairing or AUX plugs to listen to my music. Don't gotta have CD's cluttered everywhere and such. I'll give modern cars that. That's it though.﻿

author: RMC Carrillo

text: I remember when controls in vehicles were all manual.  I found that this manual control more integrates the driver with the car/truck.  I have found that with manual control, the vehicle is more memorable and fun and endearing.  I had a '56 Dodge Power Wagon with three levers on the floor.  They were the shift lever for the transmission, the hi-lo-lolo lever for speed ranges and the 4-wheel drive-2-wheel drive lever.  Today, you're lucky to have a shift lever.  The drive selector is a push button.  What's so endearing about that?  What's so memorable about that.  I've had vehicles that were finicky and fraught with little problems that, at the time, were bothersome, but on reflection help to make that car/truck a warm memory.  Soon we won't have to drive our cars.  You might as well take a taxi.﻿

author: Glory M

text:
Great ending. :D

I actually like the screen up where I can see it. Function before design. "Fake vents", not really; look at them as place holders for mods. Turbos, "on the cheaper cars": really? How about some cheap cars have turbos? "Slap a turbo on it." Okay, the CHEAP cars, but not the well conceived, designed and produced cars. If not having a turbo and still having 500 FP of torque means spending well over $100K to get a not cheap naturally aspirated engine, then I guess all less expensive high performance cars with turbos are "cheap". Well, at least they aren't as expensive; but I wouldn't say that either side of $40K is "cheap". If EV take over, they will need to make some kind of noise to keep pedestrians safe; so "fake engine noise" tech seems the obvious way to go. Big wheels and high aspect ratio tires are not just about looks: the stiffer sidewalls make for better handling and grip in the corners. "Spirited" (aggressive) drivers are always craving better handling. The thing I hate about them is curb rash.

My favorite hate trend is the massive grill look (Lexus is the biggest sinner). May it die.﻿

author: Al Kaput

text:
Stalk screens - biggest issue with these is the heat.  In sunny areas, there's no "cushion" between the screen electronics and the hot plastic
Fake vents - in some (definitely not all) cases, the fake vent hides an option that wasn't include in the car, such as fog lights, etc.
Turbo Chargers - In some cases, the turbo is required because the engines are so badly tuned (in order to operate) or so under powered, without the turbo the car is just a paperweight.
Resonators - Why would you expect "varoom-varoom" 600hp resonator sound to come across as real on a mini-van or 4-cylinder?  I mean, really :(
Speaking of stupid trends, here's more;
- fog lights!  White light BLINDS in fog, and therefore you can't use them in foggy conditions.
- High beams (with or without auto-dim).  "Low beam" Halogen lights are more than adequate for driving unless installed incorrectly, mis-aimed or damaged.  Fix the damned aiming.  I'm sick and tired of driving into a sun because some lazy ass won't turn his high beams down.
- Ceiling DVD pull down screens where Down means zero rear view mirror.  Stupid!﻿

author: Randy Ladwig

text: I am SOOOO sick of tiny cars with 4 cylinder engines and CVT transmissions. Since most manufacturers are going to small motors and little vehicles, I am doomed to buy pre-owned. This is not all bad, since depreciation has (mostly) happened, and the warranty on Certified Used Cars is sometimes more comprehensive (and longer) than that of a new car. I long for the days of a beefy V8 Caddy or Lincolns (or Lexus or MB or Audi) and genuine shifts from the transmission, not to mention the wheelbase and length that makes you feel like you are 'getting what you paid for' and driving something substantial. I truly HATE trucks and SUV/CUVs... unless, of course, they are job necessary. But the sight of a 4'11" driver sitting 2 inches from the steering wheel, doing 65mph in a 45 zone while driving a Chevrolet Suburban pulling a camper, sunglasses on, cell phone in hand, nose planted firmly in the rearview mirror watching the kiddies... gives me night terrors. And before I am labelled, I am by no means discriminating against vertically challenged, GM driving, road raging parents with short arms and light sensitivity in a hurry who can't seem to find the entrance to the local campground... certainly not my intention... merely an example. That is my 2 cents worth, as they say...﻿

author: Hin11

text: @Hin11 Yeah, it works great until it doesn't. A very experienced engineer once said: parts left out cost nothing and don't brake. Is it really asking too much to operate the parking brake yourself?﻿
author: tempest411

text: @tempest411 No, it isn't asking too much to operate the parking brake, but so far it hasn't broken and I like the way it works.  Taking the discussion a bit further, I guess my shoes work great until the lace breaks one day; I guess the roll up driverside window on my '74 Pinto worked great until the pot metal handle broke off in my hand one day...couldn't roll up the window; I guess all things work great until they break or wear out.  So why buy or use anything that has the possibility of failure?  I think that's a lazy argument for denigrating something you don't like.﻿
author: Hin11

text: @Hin11 No it's not. Part of intelligent design is considering maintenance and repair. Does it really make sense to replace $100.00 of hardware with several hundred $ of hardware, adding complexity to the design and repair...all in the name of gimmicky creature comfort? When the parking fails in a manual design it usually takes just a few minutes to figure it out and udually less than $20.00 to fix. But on an electro-mechanical design there's more to consider because there more possible points of failure. I' m sure the actuators they use are a lot more than $20.00. It's just dumb...﻿
author: tempest411

text: @tempest411 Part of intelligent design for things mechanical (not the psuedoscience of evolution/creation) is considering customer convenience, predictability of MTBF, as well as maintenance and repair.  Does your current car have power windows?  Does your current car have power brakes and steering?  Does your current car have air conditioning?  Does it have a navigation system?  Does it have a backup camera?  Does it have electrically actuated and operated seats? If so, why?  All those things can be done away with (as they didn't exist for decades) or will/may break.  Those things and other conveniences are, considering maintenance and repair, worth it to me and, literally, millions of others.  You are, it seems to me, making an assumption that an electronic parking brake is destined to fail...it's inevitable.  Well, you're wrong.  Some will fail but the vast majority (probably in the 90+% range I'd guess) will never fail.  I can afford to replace my power window actuators/motors, air conditioning parts, electrically actuated/operated seat motors.  I want a backup camera, a nav system (built into the dash).  All those things can and may fail, I don't care, I can afford the once in a lifetime failure/fix while enjoying the 99% uptime.  The parking brake issue you're making is nonsense to me given the likelihood of it ever failing.  I didn't buy my current daily driver because it had an electric parking brake, but it is convenient, I've used it hundreds of times, and it hasn't failed.  If you don't like them, I'm fine with that.  Don't buy a car with one if it makes you feel better about your choices.  I'm declaring the horse dead; answer if you must but I'm finished.  Sincerely, have a great day and a Happy New Year.﻿

text: How or when did we actualy start to call the emergency brake a f****ing parking brake. Just try to park your car during 1 week or longer at minus 15°celcius, your so called parkingbrake will be frozen﻿
author: beucky

text: beucky I don’t know about the car you drive but on all my standard transmission cars the parking brake is used every time I park the car, to hold it in place so it doesn’t move.  It’s not safe to only leave the car in gear, I have personally had cars move in that circumstance because of low compression from worn piston rings.  So it’s a parking brake.  The one time I had an emergency when when the hydraulic brakes failed (on a 1990 Civic) I pulled the parking brake to use it as an “emergency” brake and it worked very poorly.  Think about it, the parking brake is only on the rear wheels and is 1/4 the size of the service brakes.  Better than nothing in an emergency but hardly something that should be called an “emergency brake.”﻿

text: GREAT GREAT Video. I fully agree with one exception: A TURBO is great. A turbo is the single item giving freedom. Engineers can play with many things: number of cylinders, intake, fuel type, RPM, but changing pressure gives you 2X improvement, not just 10%. My 1.4TFSI from Skoda/VW is amazing. It works much better with the automatic gear shifting then my older 2.0FSI without turbo. Really much better, also the sound! The 1.4T gives you good power at 2000RPM, whereas the 2.0 wo. turbo was always rotating much higher. I have to admit that I have a leased car, so I do not know what happens beyond 70,000 miles. My older 2.0TSFI Audi A5 had bad problems with oil consumption, but not with the turbo.﻿

author: Rodzilla

text: @Rodzilla When I was 22, I could drive a Chevette (where I actually had to open the car door to be able to actuate the clutch pedal!). But now I'm 62, and the legs don't bend like they used to.  I can't sit with my legs folded for any length of time, or the ache and then searing pain gradually increases so in about half an hour, I'm about to scream because it hurts so much.  I need to be able to straighten out my legs. Something to do with the effects of tendonitis & arthritis. So even though I could potentially get into a smaller car, it would hurt like hell to bend my knees to a 90 degree angle just to get into it, and would hurt more because I could never straighten them out. BTW the pants I wear are a 36" inseam, if that describes my leg length better. Oh, BTW, when I was a kid, there WERE cars with plenty of legroom.  Over time, they disappeared, as the corporations simply stopped making them in order to save money, and just focused on making cars for the average sized people, and the big folks were screwed. I had a 1986 928 which I could just barely fit into and stretch out once I was in it; after that, I had to always unbolt the seats, and fashion a home made steel bracket about 4" further back, making sitting behind me impossible for anyone who had legs. The second reason for a large SUV is, I've worked in emergency rooms all my life. During the winters, we always have old guys either getting heart attacks from trying toshovel snow, or hurting themselves pushing cars or slipping on ice. A big SUV means never shoveling yourself out of the snow. Just leave it in 4WD when parked before it snows. 2' of snow? Who cares. I've even climbed over plowed in 3' high plowed mounds of iced crud with my Broncos and now Expy, with only the stock 31" tires. So; no heart attacks for me, or back injuries due to snow. All because of having the right car.﻿

author: R Soul

text: Agree with a lot of your points, but really? Plastichrome? That's been around since at least the early 70s. Not really a trend. Turbos...pretty much every diesel on the road has 'em...for decades now. Big wheels started in the 80s with 16 inchers over 14s as an option. They do serve a purpose other than looks, though. A bigger tire has a larger circumference, allowing longer run out and better tire life. In the 80s I was replacing tires every 20k -30k miles. Now it's more like 50k. Tire technology has dramatically improved as well, but part of that is having a tire circumference of 90 inches as opposed to 70 inches the 80s, for example. That's about 150 less revolutions per mile, allowing tires to last longer. Definitely agree about the tacked on afterthought of some touch screens. As you mentioned, though, so many of the trends are consumer driven. I just have difficulty classifying something that's been around for 30 or more  years as a trend.﻿

author: baba yaga

text:
I generally agree with the vast majority of your opinions...especially in videos like this one.

Another trend that is really ruining it is increasing blind spots and poor visibility in favour of the tear drop belt line styling, which all manufacturers are adopting. Large windows, thin pillars and low belt lines are underrated; there are definitely ways of designing towards more outward visibility without compromising safety and crash-ability.

Driver assistance features are flat out terrible and shouldn't even be an option. On the surface, we may think that they reduce accident occurrences, but in reality it is quickly making us dependant on the machine doing everything for us. We will become poorer drivers because of these systems as we lose good habits. For the good driver, they are an annoyance at best.

And lastly, we're trading in substance for gimmicks with our new cars. True innovation is becoming a rarity, but hey look at this new digital cluster no one asked for. Everything is a screen, has a screen or turns into a screen. I don't know about you guys, but I spend my entire work day in front of 2 screens. It would be refreshing to get back into my car and not have yet another screen stare at me for the length of my drive. It's the first thing I do when I get behind the wheel of my 2014 Mazda3; I turn the damn screen off.

I wish the automotive market would build a few cars barebone but solid driver-oriented cars to my taste. Too bad it's oversatured with turbocharged automatic CUVs with touch screens and lane departure warning.

edit: and the electric hand brake. ** that thing.﻿

author: Smarchitect Mann

text: Give me a car that with basic maintenance can go 300,000 miles. Every goddamn contemporary car made is now a pile of electronic gimmickry that will start failing soon after the service warranty expires. A vehicle's pedigree used to be tied to its trouble-free longevity. Today a new Rolls Royce gets fixed as often as an Alfa or a Jag ever did, but for far more money. Super-car resale values drop like an anvil out a 3rd story window after 10,000 miles. And so do their ability to get the owner home without the aid of a AAA flat-bed. They have turned one of mankind's most liberating inventions into a self-imposed fiscal enslavement predicated to man's innate ego-centrism and indoctrinated consumerism.﻿

text:
"
The Worst Trend in Modern Cars and Trucks"................................................
The fucking auto-dimming mirror is the worst gadget I've EVER seen in cars. WHO asked for the auto-dimming mirror????.......I didn't. Here's how the auto-dimming mirror works. I takeoff down the road at night and a car approaches from the rear. The car's headlights shine in my eyes, blinding me, and auto-dimming mirror dims to the night time setting. That car turns off and the mirror goes full bright again. Another car turns in behind me and that hideous scenario plays out again. Or, a car is behind me and the mirror is dimmed.......I turn a corner and the trailing car's lights go out of view.....my mirror goes bright......the car follows me around the corner and I am blinded once again while the fucking mirror goes through it's dimming cycle. WHO ASKED FOR AN AUTO-DIMMING MIRROR ? ? ? ???????.........I've never heard ANYONE say "Gee, I wish my mirror would dim automatically."  Never heard anyone say that EVER.﻿

author: szymenxd

text:
Just a simple two cent thrown in: Keyless entry, remote start, alarm, hideaway door handles... do these function if the vehicle thinks it's in operation or the key is present inside the vehicle?  I have a vehicle that now requires the key to be put into the keyhole in the door to be unlocked because a 3 year old broke the ignition switch making the car think the key is always present in the vehicle.

Key fob push button start: Have a friend who drove his wife to work and then drove to his own work.  On the commute home, he was stranded because the fob was in HER purse, neither thought about the fob leaving the vehicle with the passenger until starting the car hours later!  10 years ago, the key was in the dash/steer column and didn't leave the vehicle without the driver.

How many servers are hacked daily?  How many companies report customers information being leaked or hacked?  A vehicle is controlled by a computer, connected to the internet for convenience, updates. reports, control by a mobile device.  One person in a foreign country hacks into a car manufacture's server and shuts down all Toyotas and Teslas in the US and Europe because they can... then what?  That 1969 Corvette is running fine, though....﻿

author: TAPriceCTR

text:
That's what I came here to say. CUVs are especially stupid. So I get to pay the same price and get the same low gas mileage as an SUV, but I get the interior space of a sedan (there's still no leg room for adult passengers despite the large size)? No thanks. 
If I need a car for just going back and forth to work every day and maybe picking up groceries once a week, I will buy a sedan.
If I need to move and tow lots of stuff regularly, I will buy a pickup truck.
If I actually need to do off-road things, I will buy a proper SUV.
If I need a lot of interior space for a family, I will buy a minivan or a station wagon.

CUVs are 🤬ing stupid!!!﻿

author: DblOSmith

text:
Most modern cars suck. End of story.
Electric cars might not pollute from the tailpipe, but they still require electricity and they're still cars!

By which I mean basing our transportation system around cars is a huge waste of money (purchasing, maintenance, road building costs), time (congestion, parking), and resources/space (highways, parking etc). Electric cars still have these problems.

It's about time that we develop in a more connected fashion and build cycle paths to get everyone on two wheels and their own feet.
Save time, money, space, and of course public physical and mental health.﻿

text: My biggest problem is a lack of willingness for dealers or manufactures to go BACK to older items. Granted I like Trucks which are more work/function oriented but you still see this crap no matter what. My Newest Ram has a grill that opens/closes depending on temp and speed. WHY?! For a couble of decimals in aerodynamics and engine operating temperature control? Its gonna break and then I have to fix something that does nothing noticeable and I couldn't even DOWNGRADE even though I wanted to. I think everyone needs to drop their ego and addiction to electronics and learn mechanical concepts again. Or at least provide people like me a market to thrive in.﻿

author: User Name

text: @User Name I've owned dozens of cars with low-pros and with normal sidewalls.  Low-pros look great but I'll never own another vehicle that has them.  They cost far more money to own in the long-term than any vehicle I've ever owned with normal tires.  Low-pros are less durable, wear out much faster, are easier to damage, are far more difficult to mount and affect ride quality significantly.  All my vehicles with "normal" tires have an average life of 60,000 miles.  All my vehicles with low-profile tires have all had about 40,000 mile lifespans.  You pay a lot of money to look good.﻿

text: I have a 2013 truck, I like the style etc, but to tell the truth, I would like to have the truck body and interior and put in a newly made 8 cyl engine with a carburetor. As they were in 1985 or 86. I would have all the electronic bull shit removed. Manuel door locks, a transmission like from an 86 or 87. Reason for using that year is because I bought a brand new Ram Charger from the factory in 87. I loved the truck and kept it until 2004. Never had a problem with it. The only problem was my lack of intelligence. Or I should say I wasn't smart enough to keep it. Oh no, it had been paid for, ran good, I was talked into a new one in 2013. Oh it's nice but it has had several recalls, which the 87 never had. The engine was a Mopar 318 cu in. One of the best motors Chrysler ever made. All the bells and whistles are bull shit and will cost a lot more if they ever go bad and everything does. Oh how I loved my 87 Ramcharger. I don't need these electronic bull shit to get me from point a to where ever, dumb, dumb etc.﻿

author: Greg Wallace

text:
This is absolutely correct. Manufacturers have taken the phrase "if it ain't broke, don't fix it" and thrown it out the window from the top story of the empire state building while Michael Bay was directing the shooting of a film on the street below. I can't believe that I, almost completely uneducated in vehicular engineering, can see how simpler = better, while thousands of technicians and engineers seem to be blind to it.
The only reasons I can think of are that manufacturers want to be able to advertise the gimmicks, at whatever cost to affordability, and I think the reduction in reliability is a benefit to them, as people have to buy more parts.
The main problem is that the cars are being bought at all: if people quit buying them until they were simplified, you just might see hand crank windows and a standard transmission in a new vehicle again.﻿

text: I couldn't agree more and yes there are a few things like autostart he missed. My son in law just bought a 6-series BMW (4-door, V8) which is a nice car to be sure but it has a computer display instead of the great old style red gauges BMW was famed for. When you start the car it displays the traditional red gauges but once underway they change. On the right hand gauge you just see a large white D indicating you are in Drive and on the left gauge you see large white numerals indicting your speed. Admittedly he just got the car, but when I asked him about it, he stopped at a traffic light, he tried unsuccessfully to change the display format using the very complicated menu system they call, I think,  i-drive!  He said he uses the heads up display on the windshield which the passenger seat.  Recently I was seized by nostalgia (about the '88 M5 and the '95 M3 that I once owned) and went looking for a used 1-series with a standard 6-speed transmission. I couldn't find one anywhere! I asked a BMW dealer about that and he said you would have order a manual transmission. Oh well, I'm too old to be driving one anyhow!﻿

author: ebin belji

text: Additional suggestion: day running lights and light switches that are beyond the intelligence of some drivers. It's become increasingly common (in the UK) to see new model cars going around after dark with no rear lights on. While they may have some lights on at the front, giving the drivers the illusion they're all lit, they're not, which indicates they don't understand 'day' is a different setting from 'On.' Sure, the buyer should read the handbook, or the selling dealership should be explaining this stuff, but the root cause of the problem has got to be the way that manufacturers are actually making vehicles with switch design [on something so fundamental to safety] so poor that it even  allows the possibility of this kind of mistake.﻿

author: Kahitanology

text:
While we are on this topic, the worst trend in modern cars is the propensity of car makers to bury everything so that even seasoned mechanics go nuts just to change a light bulb or fix a five dollar hose. There is no reason why an auto maker cannot add a few extra inches in either direction under the hood so that people can access basic things such as hoses, belts, batteries and more without having to remove major assemblies. It seems as if the auto makers are purposely burying things just to keep people from fixing their own cars or going to a mechanic other than the one at the dealer.

The next major peeve is the unwarranted denial of information necessary to reset the on board computers after a repair or event causes an error. We seriously need to pass a right to repair act to force all makers of anything to provide all information necessary for the owner to service the product themselves if they choose to do so. The cock and bull excuses given by manufacturers that there is proprietary information in the computer is nothing but a load of garbage given to fool lawmakers into allowing the ripoff to continue. This trend has been getting worse as the number and sophistication of computers in the products we buy continues to rise. All manufacturers of anything computerized should be required to include a backup disc or thumb drive with all necessary resets and full instructions to enable a normal person to reset their onboard computers to nominal status after a physical repair or event causes a glitch in the system. There is no reason for the current ripoff to continue.

On the positive side, a nice basic work truck and a nice basic low priced big family car and/or SUV would be nice as well. All of the American auto makers made such a thing right up through the middle 1990s and then stopped. We need to bring back the unbreakable slant six which all the big automakers made some version of to power such vehicles. The tiny, feature packed, mechanically inaccessible little compacts which masquerade as family cars are not sufficient. They are just as difficult to repair as the higher end cars in many cases and they are plagued with the same arrogant attitude about onboard computers which need to be reset to the tune of hundreds and sometimes thousands of dollars for a ten second download at the dealer.

Perhaps what we really need is for some enterprising entrepreneur to develop a universal replacement for all or most of the on board computers used in today's vehicles which will run all of the mechanical functions so an owner can throw away the ripoff proprietary computers. There is a serious potential for hackers and organized crime to rip off the codes so that we can bypass the dealer and manufacturer ripoff. Given the attitude problem on the part of most auto makers, it would serve them right.﻿

author: Doug Meserve

text:
@Selim Sultan Akbar That's not true. Tactile controls allow the operator to develop a muscle memory to use said controls without looking or with the quickest of glances. Even if you learn at which part of the screen certain functions exist, you must still precisely touch that spot while you and the vehicle are moving independent of one another, and that can only happen after you've verified you're on the correct screen in the first place.

author: Jim Porter

text: @Jim Porter I thought Mazda hit on a great idea a while back but they have since given in to the tablet-on-dash concept. My 2007 CX-9 had what I called and eyebrow display at the top center of the dash. It shows the temperature for driver/passenger or system/outside, the HVAC status, and the entertainment system information all in a bright, easy to read display that was visible regardless of the lighting conditions. All the controls were tactile and intuitive. That allowed the driver to look at one spot for that information without having to guess which info was being displayed. With the addition of Navigation and EVs which have other information to display, I'd like to see the displays mimic that arrangement by having a fixed set of information across the top for all the basic functions and the open part be used for nav and system display with limited pages, and all controls remain tactile including page scroll and zoom. That eliminates the distraction and keeps the screen clean. The knobs and buttons in my CX-9 weren't physically connected to anything and only sent signals to a processor, so they were far simpler to engineer and install compared to having cables and huge wiring harnesses.﻿

author: ThomasHOL

text:
@Sven Blubber There is one exception to controllable CVT's and that's when doing a down hill decent and you would like to maintain a high gear to reduce use of brakes and engine brake. Other then that geared automatic transmissions already switch between max fuel efficiency and and power (achievable by the gearing ratio) based on throttle input. Current CVT's also do this with out a paddle or button, the problem is they simulate either a 6,7,8 etc. speed transmission so the common person who can't understand how a CVT works does not freak out when the car is holding 5k RPM for extended periods of times, however this reduces the acceleration of the car. 

Simulated gear CVT's often have a slight downside in terms of fuel efficiency during highway since when you are at a constant speed and low throttle input the CVT should maintain the lowest gear ratio possible. The problem is in the performance department when simulated gear shifts defeat the purpose of CVT's performance wise.﻿

author: Kyle Butler

text: @Jonathan Chen Sorry bro but you are completely wrong. Yes CVTs are great for economy but acceleration is laggy at best. Just because engine revs are high doesn't mean the car is accelerating the "quickest". Take a standard transmission for example, you can rev it out in 1st gear and still be going 30mph. Or you can be doing a much lower rpm in a higher gear and be going 100mph. Same thing in a CVT, where revs may be high but it relies on the transmission "changing ratios" to accelerate, rather than gear changes. Often when you force the engine to maintain high revs, the car still feels sluggish, due to the CVT having to change the ratio to change the speed of the car while the revs stay constant. CVTs are not designed to be sporty or quick, and when you rev the shit out of the engine it defeats the purpose of it, while still getting shit performance lol. I know the way I explained may not be perfectly clear, but do some research yourself, you will understand what I mean.﻿

author: The Bruce

text:
Glad I found your channel, I agree with everything you say here. As a new car buyer, I find it very tiring sifting through all the unneccessary crap that's either part of the vehicle or coming out of the salesman's mouth. I really wish they had stayed away from CVT transmissions too. Or at least until they had got them more reliable, quieter, and with greater load capacity for towing. Most are only 750kg unbraked, which represents a tiny single axle garden trailer loaded with grass clippings .
I hate the piano black plastic as it scratches so easily, gets static charged and retains dust and dirt. Plastic chrome is tacky and cheap. And, as you pointed out, 18 or 20" Wheels all very fine until it comes time to buy new ones. $250 each for the new Subaru Outback, and that's the cheapest price I could find for a reasonably good quality tire. That does not include fitting and balancing and the disposal fee for the old tires. That's right, old tires are such a pollutant they charge a disposal fee in the country I mostly reside in. The touch screens on some some cars are not touch screens at all but plastic pressure screens that require more pressure to operate and lag, like the ones in the 2015 Ford Fusion and Mondeo. But at least they are part of the dashboard and not an intrusive, in the way wall, sticking up on top of the dashboard. As for Turbo's, I actually liked the one in the Ford that delivered about 240 HP from a 2 liter gasoline engine. But, glad I don't have one now, as the fuel economy in the latest 2.5 gasoline Outback is nothing short of amazing. Some of this would be attributed to the CVT trannie I think. Though I would have preferred a regular hydraulic transmission that will most likely last longer and take more load and torque without slipping. author: zdravo

text:
2010s car trends as a whole suck. They're crap now and they'll age even worse.

Crossovers. Ugh. Yeah, make your hatchback stupidly high so it handles worse, is less aerodynamic, heavier, and has no more usable space, all while mounting the headlights level with my roof so that for the 6 months of the year when I do all my driving at night, i've got what looks like full beams shining in my face or in my mirrors. Same with the trend of driving big 4x4s, which fed the whole crossover thing.

Plastic anything on anywhere that gets hot. This has been a problem for a long time though, but its only getting worse. Include any kind of external water pump/plastic water pump impellors (BMW and Audi had a race to the bottom on this)

Low profile wheels with hard suspension to make everything feel sporty without actually having to engineer quality suspension which gives a well handling car that is also not backbreaking to drive. Not so much a problem in Germany where the roads are good quality, but in the third world of the UK, it's unbearable. Not to mention its easy to kerb up wheels when there is no tyre to protect them.

Bullshit fuel economy figures. In the early 2000s you could actually achive them, but now, not a chance. Emissions standards have a lot to answer for too. They haven't done much in actually lowering real world emissions, but have succeeded in adding a bunch of pointless crap to cars. Many current cars are much less fuel effecient than previous versions because they are so much bulkier, and have to cope with downsized engines that drink through needing to be worked hard with a turbo spun up all the time.

Oh, and before I forget, Dual clutch gearboxes. None of the reward from driving a manual, and more to go wrong. I've driven a GTR, which supposedly has one of the better ones, but I really did not get on with that box.﻿

author: Freekofnayture

text: Fake engine noise? Disgusting! Hidden door handles, big deal.... Technology, I own a 2018 Accord and while I like the car in general I've had more problems with it because of the technology than any other car I've owned. Example, my TPMS light kept going off even after I had a slow leak fixed, i thought it was the sensor or some software issue. I would recalibrate to turn the light off knowing my air pressure was just fine but to no avail. I found a software fix for it that hasn't been rolled out in mass and was preparing to have it loaded however in reading some articles I found 1 article that said after recalibration you must drive the car for 20-30 minutes between 30-60 MPH in order for the calibration to take affect. What! Can you imagine having to do that after every air fill? I did like it said and guess what , no TPMS light for a week now. Good lord that is ridiculous. The least manufacturers can do is test, test, test before putting out a sensor that needs babysitting after every calibration. Needless to say, I doubt everyone knows about this but me. Yea it's probably in the manual but even the dealership couldn't tell me this. KISS is the way to go until technology has these things locked down.﻿

text: Hate to burst your bubble goose man, but integrated handles actually help with aerodynamics. A car without side mirrors would get up to 2-4 mpg better. Roof racks can reduce your MPG by up to 4 -6 MPG.  They call this research, science, & engineering. So I guess you think doors for gas caps are stupid too. These are not all Trends  worth discussing. This is your subjective dislike of design trends. Real trends are things like 4 cyl 2.0 liter turbo vs. inline 6 vs V8, AWD vs RWD or FWD,  dual clutch vs single, alloy body vs steel, electric vs. gas or diesel vs. hybrid, small trucks vs.big trucks...major changes to how we use cars and interact with them how they are engineered, and to what markets are they selling to. those are trends worth discussing, not black plastic trim or fake vents. Bring some real information to the discussion.﻿

author: Alex Damm

text: This is why I buy BMWs. Yes, they follow trends like everyone else. But they don't put things (especially their interiors) that don't make sense or that don't directly contribute to the driver experience. They've bowed to consumer pressure for "more premium" tricked-out interiors. But even so, the autompress consistently criticizes Bimmer for "being too conservative." Well, just drive one for a week or two. You still get ACTUAL MECHANICAL BUTTONS AND DIALS...for every non-electronic function. And their iDrive information is intuitive and butt-simple to use. Also, yes, they use turbos...but twin scroll bi-turbos that spin up smoothly without lag, and turn an otherwise solid little four into a rocket.﻿
author: Robert Bruce

text: Niche complaint to add but I see it every day at work and it drives me crazy: stop hiding the battery under a bunch of engine cover plastic and stop putting the battery deep in the engine out of easy reach. The worst is the kind that provide an accessible positive terminal connection for boosting but neglect to put anything specific for your ground. Steel bolts in modern cars do not work well as ground points (or won't work at all), everything else in the engine is painted. The only company I have seen do the hidden battery thing intelligently is Porsche: well marked positive connection and also well marked copper (brass?) ground lug.﻿
author: Stout Lager

text:
Excellent points especially @5:40, and those big low profile wheels aren't the best for Canadian roads in the spring pothole season. 

Here's my list of things that bug me about modern cars:

-The daytime lights turn on with the gauges making you think that you are driving with your lights on at night. It may be bright up front, but the taillights are off. I always thought this was so stupid. 

-Lack of a spare tire, some cars provide just a can with a substance that is supposed to plug the hole in the flat tire. What if that tire has a huge gash or a blowout? 

-Lack of a dipstick/filler tube for the transmission on most modern cars, making oil changes more difficult. 

- Lack of of a dipstick for something as basic as checking the engine oil.

- TOO MANY PLASTIC PARTS

-Some luxury cars /SUVs don't have a mechanical handle to open the tailgate. They rely on a sensor that you put your finger over to open it.

-Uncomfortable ride compared to large cars from the 70's to the early 90's. 

-Like you said, I don't want to go thru a menu and a touchscreen  just to change the volume or the temperature of the cabin. Switches and knobs do a better job at this. 

-A question for Ford: Why did you get rid of the Crown Victoria? Why did you get rid of the Econoline? 

-This one is not as important but still matters: Lack of style. Today's cars are so bland, there are some exceptions like the Ford Mustang, Dodge Challenger and the Chrysler 300. Even theses are lame compared to cars prior to the 90s'


Let me know if you agree!﻿

text: I love this. Great video. More, please! author: Lourens de Bruyn

text: Probably the worst trend is the complicated touch-screen where you have to look at and navigate a menu screen to do basic functions like turn on the climate control or adjust the radio. Where is the difference between this and texting while driving? Automatic transmissions in all their forms are dangerous in that the driver no longer has to concentrate and anticipate road conditions , especially when the automatic often shifts into an entirely inappropriate gear, dumping lots of torque where a gentle nudge is all that is needed. An experienced driver with a manual can use the throttle, clutch and the selective sliding gears to adjust precisely to the road conditions. And who needs fake engine noise when I can hear my neighbors' Mustangs and Challengers and Camaros and Chargers coming three blocks away?﻿

author: pete5668

text: Fake engine noise? Why? Electronic door handles? Look at the handles on a '56 Chrysler. No electronics to break, just push on the handle ahead of the pivot point and you can grab the pull. Infotainment? Overcomplicated tech? Touch screens? Anything that requires any shift of attention from the immediate business of operating the vehicle is lethally dangerous. Oversize wheels and tires? I couldn't get power windows and locks without the 265 tires on 16 inch wheels, and had to add a step bar to get into it. Who needs turbos? "There's no replacement for displacement", to quote Bentley when his engineers pushed blowers in the 1920s. Fake vents sometimes plug holes in the bumper or bodywork where accessories such as driving lights might be installed if the higher end models. And was it George Orwell who called advertising "...rattling a stick in the swill bucket..."?﻿

author: T ridder

text:
Indeed. Cars have been fine-tuned a lot and dynamics have gotten better, but at the end of the day, the industry is as corrupt as it's always been. Electric cars might not pollute from the tailpipe, but they still require electricity and they're still cars!

By which I mean basing our transportation system around cars is a huge waste of money (purchasing, maintenance, road building costs), time (congestion, parking), and resources/space (highways, parking etc). Electric cars still have these problems.

It's about time that we develop in a more connected fashion and build cycle paths to get everyone on two wheels and their own feet.
Save time, money, space, and of course public physical and mental health.﻿

author: James Pulver

text: combustion of gasoline is a chemical reaction, with the ideal combination of air and fuel.  this CANNOT be improved. period.  flow, aerodynamics, rotational mass, and frictional losses can, but not combustion.  It can be modified to increase power, or decrease fuel consumption, but the proper ratio of air to fuel needs to remain the same﻿
author: KingOfPoop

text:
@KingOfPoop The chemical reaction can always be improved because combustion occurs efficiently under optimal conditions. If there is not enough oxygen in the chamber, then your fuel will combust incompletely, leaving CO (Carbon monoxide, which is highly toxic) and C (the black soot shit) as byproducts instead of CO_2. Reactions, including combustion reactions are not just limited to the concentration of reactants, but the temperature of the engine, the pressures within the chamber, etc. This is basic high school chemistry. 

Of course there are thermodynamic friction losses throughout the rest of the vehicle, but internal combustion can always be improved. It's why there are fewer pollutants that exit your engine at the end of the day, and it's also part of the reason why newer airplane jet engines, despite the planes having relatively the same design since the 50s, are still getting far more efficient. Of course, with planes, the differences is more of a fluid dynamics issue, but the improving the efficiency of the combustion reaction is a significant part.﻿
author: Toronto Transit Channel

text: @Toronto Transit Channel A better idea would be to simply switch to electric vehicles. About 10x more efficient in converting stored chemical energy into motion than internal combustion is. Plus, IC will always require the use of non renewable fossil fuels while electric cars can use electricity from the sun, wind, etc.﻿

text:
Yeah, modern cars suck.
Even electric cars might not pollute from the tailpipe, but they still require electricity and they're still cars!

By which I mean basing our transportation system around cars is a huge waste of money (purchasing, maintenance, road building costs), time (congestion, parking), and resources/space (highways, parking etc). Electric cars still have these problems.

It's about time that we develop in a more connected fashion and build cycle paths to get everyone on two wheels and their own feet.
Save time, money, space, and of course public physical and mental health.﻿

author: Severity One

text:
One thing about the screen being glued to the dashboard: There's a good reason for that: a) They can design the rest of the dashboard in a more attractive way, and more importantly b) the screen is higher up, in the drivers sight. That means you don't have to look down to control things, which in turn makes it safer to operate. With the amount of features a modern car (luckily) has, doing it all via buttons isn't an option. I am annoyed by car manufacturers removing buttons altogether, or replacing them with touch sensitive buttons (I'm looking at you, VW! The infotainment systems in the facelifted Golf are a big step backwards, and moving climate controls to the screen is just stupid and bad design!), but having a screen itself isn't the issue. It's how they pick what features they put on buttons and which they don't.

IMHO the pre-facelift Golf Mk 7 infotainment systems are amongst the best there are. You have a step surrounding the screen, which means you have a place you can rest your fingers to stabilize them on bumpy roads. There are also physical buttons around the screen to let you switch to different menus and functions, and you can blindly feel where you are without looking. There's a sensor that knows when your hand is near the screen, so when there isn't it maximizes the viewing area. Once you get closer to the screen, the buttons appear. All climate controls are placed in a separate area, where they are laid out logically. There are dials where necessary, too. And, very important too, the infotainment unit is structured in a logical way. You'll easily find what you are looking for. It could be mounted a bit higher, but it's still reasonable.

With the facelift they replaced the buttons with touch buttons, the screen is much glossier, slippier AND it doesn't have a lip that gives the fingers support so they stay in place (so on bumpy roads you're going to be all over the place. These small changes turn it into a usability nightmare.﻿

author: Ayas Muthanna

text:
An interesting video and I agree with a lot it.  However, I am a bit surprised that you didn't talk about a certain trends that are becoming more and more of an increase problem for us everyday drivers and I blame part of the problem on our government ever since they deregulate them.  The damn auto manufacturers wanted headlights deregulated so they can have an easier time in designing new cars.  But unfortunately this has created a new problem for us other drivers which we are forced to deal with everyday and is only become more and more of an increasing problem.  For instance, a lot of new car headlights on SUV and trucks are positioned to high where they beam directly into an on coming driver eyes thus blinding them which creates a safety risk and potential driving hazard.  Furthermore, to make matters worst many of these new cars are now using hi intensity lights where their low beams are just as intense as their high beams.  Which now creates an even greater chance for accidents this to occur.

There is another growing trend that you didn't mention as well and is huge problem now.  Many new cars have super bright daytime driving lights where a lot of drivers do not either realize nor bother to turn on there main lights during nighttime driving.  I cannot tell you how many cars I have encountered during nighttime that do not have their tail lights on at all and only further add to road hazards especially in fog, heavy rain and snow.

Our government needs to bring back regulations to the auto manufacturers industry since they cannot seem to be responsible enough to build a car correctly.   Also all new cars should be equipped with the following standard equipment:

Permitted auto-on lights - since the driver cannot be trusted to turn them on.
Car remotes - safety reason.
Heated door mirrors - safety reason.
Radio controls on steer wheel - safety reason.
Backup camera - safety reason.
Black box with cameras front, sides and rear for accident and safety protection.
Lane changing system - safety reason.
Auto brake system - safety reason.
Hands-free Bluetooth- safety reason.﻿

author: Tom Whitehall

text:
Wrong. In the US rearview cameras will be demanded by law soon and it is expected that other countries will implement similar regulations as well.
Also, you don't understand the business model that makes the German car industry so crushing and so more successful than anybody else:
The margin on a base model with basic functions is small. The margin on options is gigantic. They make the money with customizability and quality options because nobody just buys a base model without anything. But the European customer is way more demanding when it comes to colors, interior etc. so that is why the German Mercedes customers can enjoy the Boutique system where you can individualize leathers, colors etc. and nobody oversees gets it. There you can only get certain packages. But same logic: The big margin is in the options.
Example: My base C63S is 86k Euro, and I put options into it, so my MSRP for my specific configuration was 115k Euro. The margin of AMG on the 86k is "OK" at best, but "Gigantic" on the 30k. And that is not a problem for me, because I am the customer and I intentionally purchased those options.
You don't have to. Nobody forces you.﻿
author: xellossaxon

text: xellossaxon First, there isn’t going to be a law implementing mandatory rear view cameras in the United States as of current or the near future. You could see a swing in trend, which has been happening, that they are more common. The best way to see what’s around you is still not being lazy and turning your head and body to look at your surroundings. There could eventually be a law placed stating vehicles from this date forward must have such equipment if it was deemed that such equipment MUST be necessary to operate a vehicle like a bumper. Second, I never said eliminate option from vehicles. Of course that’s what attracts certain buyers to a vehicle is having something with more bells and whistles. What I’m saying is eliminating a base model car and forcing you to have what use to be options as standard is hurting the consumers. The price of a nice reliable car keeps escalating to the price of a small house. If you had a base model with less tech you don’t need more customers would be purchasing new cars more often. It’s a no brainer that manufacturers make more money off options. That’s just business 101. I don’t need to understand the German market as I live in the United States. So this is the market that concerns me.﻿

author: Redie_Games101

text:
The 1980's were all about the turbocharger. Ford started out bolting a turbo onto unmodified 2.3L 4 cylinders. Reliability was terrible. So they did a major design overhaul of the 2.3L for the turbo. At some point Ford gave up on the turbo 4 in the Mustang because when driven appropriately (hammer down as often as possible) the T4 got worse mileage than the 302 V8.

Remember the Buick Reatta? In all but its final year it had a monochrome CRT touchscreen in the dash to operate pretty much everything, and its user interface was horrible. The system was also available the same years on the larger Riviera, which the 2 seater Reatta was based on.

Replacing the CRT with a color LCD and mini computer to replicate all its original functions, but with a better UI, along with adding things like GPS, rearview camera etc, would be a fun project. All the new kit should fit within the space freed up by replacing the CRT with an LCD.﻿

text:
I got to ride around in my sister in law's new Cadillac CT6. Nice car but the infotainment and "Wowee!" technology is overboard. My. 100 brother drove it like a Corvette - 100+ mph - down in TX but other than just enjoying the ride it was crazy complicated. 
My 26 year old Fleetwood is 1/10th as advanced but I enjoy it more. It also has 15" wheels and big sidewalls. It has a nice factory sound system with a non working cassette player..hah!
Can you purchase a pickup with 15" wheels on it? I don't see where the skinny tuner wheels/tires are any good for real world use with a truck. They don't look "cool" to me; more like a kid's transformer toy. Why do car manufacturers tune the exhaust systems on Mustangs, Camaros and Challengers to sound like they are Street Stock cars capable of 10 sec 1/4 mile runs? 
That kind of noise is irritating after a while.
A trend I will never get over is the need for dual exhaust; fake or not. If it sells they will attach it with 3M tape.


My number one peeve. A lack of real bumpers. Plastic and Styrofoam isn't a true bumper.﻿

author: J M

text: God I know i'm going to get so much shit for this but thank christ the motorcycle industry hasn't gone down the shitter... Yes of course motorcycles are a "toy" to most, but you pay so damn little and get an engine 200hp per liter (NA) and revs to 15,000 RPM and still lasts upwards of 100,000 miles of hard ass riding with noting but valve adjustments. Every part serves a purpose as anything unnecessary is cut off to save weight, Expensive computer technology (like 6-axis IMUs) are used only for making faster lap times and to help you manage the often completely insane engines, yet still use very simple wiring harnesses to save weight and cut down complexity... Of course I am more than open to the fact that motorcycles are more than impractical, I'm just saying that car manufacturers need to see what actually makes a machine good instead of just wasting the consumers time and money with all of this bullshit... Also wouldn't non-dealer mechanics be getting steadily screwed over by all of this Bullshit that car manufacturers are pulling off?﻿

author: 👽MrHalcyonmusic👽

text:
I completely agree with everything you say - but then I would, I'm a 69-year old, Luddite, technophobe fossil. Some of this crud is not just irritating, but downright dangerous. I travel a lot on business and have to drive a lot of rental cars. Let me tell you, there is nothing more irritating, time-wasting and distracting than picking up a different car in a strange and dark airport car park, and then having to try to figure out just how to execute the most basic of functions. Having said that, I must admit I love GPS - it used to be a case of trying to drive a strange car, in a strange town and read a map - especially nasty in darkness.
I notice that 6.8K people gave this video a thumbs down - that's quite a lot of people who must, then, actually like the gimmicks and fake rubbish being installed on cars these days. What I find telling is that, these days, at least in my country of residence, car adverts concentrate almost solely on telling you about how many USB ports, etc, etc the vehicle has. Don't dynamics, comfort, safety, driving pleasure, etc count anymore, or are they all considered givens?﻿

author: Jay G

text:
You sound outdated and obsolete. Tesla either mitigate those issues, or they are technically justified or is simply irrelevant for an electric car. 

-No fake noise in a Tesla.
-Flush door = better aerodynamic.
-Tesla has by far the best infotainment, and would have been A YES to your question.
-Tesla is the only manufacturer to have FREE over the air updates, so your car is IMPROVING with time.
-Tire size and glossy finish are subjective.
-No turbo in a Tesla. Regulation is not the problem, polluting ICE is.
-No fake vent on a Tesla. No cancer inducing pipe either, fake or not.
-Tesla does not make ads. ZERO. You can't lie with ads if you don't have ads... The cars are so good, they sell by themselves with happy customers word of mouth and tons of positive review videos, nothing more. The product stands on its own, by itself. No lies required. Best car ever, by any possible metric. And yet, you never even mention them. 

I have one question for you: Did you ever even sat in a Tesla? As I highly doubt you ever drove one..  I dare you to just go and rent a Model 3 performance for 1 week. Affraid you'll like it too much?!?

Tesla is literally the answer to EVERYTHING you have a problem with, and yet, you didn't even mention their name ONCE!!! That truly pissed me off fantastically. As if Tesla did not exist at all or not even remotely close be worthy of your time. Incredibly insulting.﻿

author: Bartonovich52

text:
Dude... yes, Teslas are much better than regular cars...
But they still require electricity and they're still cars!

By which I mean basing our transportation system around cars is a huge waste of money (purchasing, maintenance, road building costs), time (congestion, parking), and resources/space (highways, parking etc). Electric cars still have these problems.

It's about time that we develop in a more connected fashion and build cycle paths to get everyone on two wheels and their own feet.
Save time, money, space, and of course public physical and mental health.﻿

author: thorsong1

text:
For me it's:
1. Footrests that are higher than the accelerator or at the wrong angle it when sitting high, I just want to put my foot on the floor.
1b. Some cars have high clutch pedals and are not adjustable, so I ride the clutch when my foot is on it in town.
2. USB & Lighter sockets in stupid places so you have to trail leads all over the place. I'd like to put my phone in a holder and plug it in at the dashboard, my dashcam could plug in at the top of the windscreen, and why not factory fitted dashcams?
3. Automatic wipers, I hate the unsettling irregularity of automatic wipers and cars that have them don't have and intermittent setting on them, why not have the option of that turny thing of the stalk change the frequency of the wipers rather than the rain sensors sensitivity or whatever it currently does?
4. The same dashboard light for side lights and dipped beam, you hardly see the green dipped beam light anymore.
5. The fact the noise for indicators is the same as hazards, even if you have both at the same time so if you're a delivery or cab driver and forget to turn off the hazards, you can pull out with them on when you meant to indicate.﻿

Many of the trends found in new cars are there as testing items for the market. Rather than spend more $m on R&D, its far quicker and easier to install them on the cars irrespective if the owners want them or not. Average new cars comes with a 3 year warranty, as long as these new gadgets lasts this long, thats all the manufacturer care, when they go wrong after, they are very expensive to repair,  people feel they must upgrade to the newer model so giving the manufactures a more continuous steady revenue stream.
Its been happening a lot more in other consumables, using more natural finite resources and materials.﻿

author: D-Frame

text:
1) Fake engine noise; This is not necessary, but its not that bad in some occasion to turn it on!

 2) Power door handle; This is not necessary, I don't want my car to have such door handles!

 3) Stuck on screens; A decent size 8 to 10 inches MFD non-reflective glass panel touch screen is good enough! One single small size MFD screen display on the middle of gauges cluster is good enough! The whole cluster screen display is not necessary especially on expensive cars which looks cheap, I won't buy these cars if I still have choice for mechanical gauges cluster to choose!

 4) Over complicated tech; These things are not necessary! I'm not James Bonds! Just a typical Average Joe! What I need is simple & durable (won't self-melt rubber plastic) mechanical type switches, buttons & selector knobs with digital red/amber LED displays! The manufacturers and designers should design and install build-in concealed type day/night security car cameras (CAM) for front/right/left/rear/fish-eye interior views system with easy download files in smart phones!     
 
 5) Infotainment; This is absolute not necessary, nearly anyone have smart phones! The car should allow to install manual Hi-Fi radio surround sounds system, GPS / Maps data system, hand-free phone system, carwings instant traffic report system are adequate for going from A to B! 
 
 6) Oversize wheels & tyres; Only for high performance sport/race cars or some expensive 7 seats SUVs! 
 
 7) Panino black shinny gloss plastic & plastic-chrome; These decoration gimmick doesn't look that bad! Again when use for long time under hot Sun and scratched! They don't look as good! Replacement or re-coating cost a lot of money!  

 8) Turbo everything; Turbo only necessary for those high performance sport / race cars / expensive cars and modern diesel vehicles. 

 9) Fake vents & exhaust tips; Cosmetic gimmick! But we can't stop manufacturers doing such things! 
  
10) Truth in marketing & advertising; This is how they spent money in their financial account to lower their tax! Some sort of tax planning! 

Other things not necessary is the electronic foot e-brake; electronic e-brake button! A good old style (very simple & practical) hand pull e-brake lever located just next close to your right leg for left hand drive is excellent design for drivers.

For 4WD vehicles the use of good old style simple 4WD selector lever is the best design option.

For all cars the use of centre located automatic / manual stick shift / electronic selector lever is the best design option as well!

All cars should included paddle shifters also good!﻿

author: alwaysopen

text:
I have two big grips with modern cars infotainment and electronic hand/park brakes. 

As some one who cares about audio quality the infotainment systems in modern cars are awful. Super over complicated, poorly designed and poor sound quality. Why do you need 19 Bose speakers that Audi put in to a Q7 too? I have a 2004 GM (a Australian Holden Berlina). It has separate climate control and a standard double DIN for the stereo with split speakers in the front and a single speaker in each of the rear doors. One of the first things I did when I got the car used was replace the factory stereo and speakers with after market models to get a much better sounding system. I just upgraded my stereo again recently to a new Sony unit that has a volume dial and supports CarPlay and Android Auto. I did the install myself, works fantastic. I can operate most the the climate control without having to take my eyes off the road and an actual volume dial is just plain sensible. I have steering wheels controls for the stereo that were factory fitted and I hooked them up to the new stereo and they all work but the volume dial is so much faster to use, I always use it instead. 

I also hate the button electronic hand brakes. Dumbest idea ever. Why over complicate it? A handle you pull up to engage the brake via a cable is simple yet effective. I get in my mums car which has one of these new brakes and I don't know if it's on or off until I start driving down the road and dash starts beeping at me. How do you do a hill start with these things? This is similar to the electronic door handles which are stupid too.

All this over the top tech is going to make these cars super expensive to repair in the future if you can get the parts. In 50 years will any of these cars even run like a 1960's E type Jag still will today?﻿

author: Winston Elston

text:
@The_Doctors_Tardis crack down on cell phone use in cars and get ride if all the none user friendly tech in the cars and thus put the "driver" back in the car and humans will be more trustworthy the driverless.

This is the problem, OEM's are taking the driver out of the car (I.e., making them less focused on driving the car) so they become more dangerous.

Put back the simplicity of buttons and knobs in fairly standardized ways across the brands and the whole game changes. 

Driverless cars are just too risky of an adventure. Hacking of being one of the biggest issues.... Piss-off the wrong person and you're a dead man walking with a driverless car... Basically if its electronic and has means to communicate with other outside electronic devices (which driverless cars have to have), it can be hacked..... Might be difficult at first but still can be nonetheless. A human on the other hand cant be...﻿
author: Chris

text: Driverless systems can be achieved using radars, no internet required. Unless there's a crazy maniac with a radar jammer, that is...﻿
author: elmohead

text:
@elmohead radar alone is simply not practical by any means... Radar nor GPS can account for / guide around temporary road detours due to construction or other reasons like flooding for example just to name one. This would require a need a real time open / active communication system and thus to open means for the system to be hacked... Then there's the TON of infrastructure needed. And really, to be efficient, all cars would have to talk to each other or you would have potential to create just as much traffic problems (if not more)..

Living in a state that is under never ending constant road construction / reconstruction, often with detours and where it floods a lot (i.e., Florida), I can tell you that without active real time communication and the TON of infrastructure, driverless cars will not work.﻿
author: Chris

text: True.﻿
author: elmohead

text: Driverless cars will be only safe when all other cars are also driverless, and human driving is prohibited. Together with smart phones, cashless economy, and internet of things, it will place us under total Big Brother surveillance. Orwell's 84 is innocent by comparison.﻿
author: Anatoly Grishin

text:
@Anatoly Grishin which is exactly why it will likely never happen. it would be virtually 100% impossible to take the human control element out of motor vehicles without EXTREMELY expensive and extensive infrastructure. Its more logical and practical to progress to driverless aircraft then it is driverless motor vehicles... But even then, you still need the crafts to communicate with each other and thus an open line to hacking..

What it boils down to ultimately is much of the technology that is supposed to make our lives easier is actually destroying us and changing us in a negative way.﻿

author: Akshat Jain

text:
1. Fake Engine Noise - I agree, however I think it would be cool to have the ability to customize the sound just for fun... Like a hellcat sound for a Prius to joke with your friends.
2. Hidden handles - Not just a gimmick... it helps with aerodynamics (the main reason Tesla uses them), and style.
3. Raised Screen - Completely disagree. Contouring the dash around the screen either lowers the screen or raises the dash... Either the screen is farther from the road or the dash obscures the road.
4. Complication - I agree mostly, but reading the comments from consumers they almost always complain if all 3000 features they saw on another vehicle isnt wedged into the base model of the vehicle they can afford. Consumer demand is driving it. Also, lower-cost vehicles usually come with simpler systems.
5. Infotainment - First it is a relic term at this point. The screen is not an entertainment screen it is used to interact with features of the vehicle and most are not intended to be used while driving... some even disable while driving. This is basically the same complaint as the previous one.
6. Large diameter wheels - I disagree for the most part. Unless the sidewall is extremely thin the problem of wheel damage and rough ride is not an issue. A larger wheel/thinner sidewall has less tire roll and instability with the control of the suspension more in the engineering rather than the unpredictable movement of air-filled rubber. There are plenty of lower cost options for tires of any size.
7. Gloss Black/chrome - Just because you don't like it doesn't mean it is stupid. Fingerprints are there whether you see them or not... I would rather see them.
8. Turbos - He addressed the regulations conflicting with consumer demand... so yeah I agree it is an issue. He didn't mention that many places in Europe now limit the displacement in vehicles.
9. Fake vents - I agree but it is subjective. 
10. Truth in advertising - No comment because I don't watch TV. 

Added problems to discuss imo
1. Auto Start/Stop
2. Offset backup cameras
3. Few 2-door options.
4. Too many standard features on base models.﻿

author: MikesCarInfo

text: And he is absolutely correct on the wheels. I live in an area with bad roads and commute  around 100 miles per day. I went through two sets of wheels before finally throwing the nice looking wheels and low profile tires in a dumpster and replacing them with higher profile tires and steel wheels. No, larger wheels do no increase fuel economy. Lower rolling resistance does. While yes, a mechanical advantage can be  had with a larger overall tire diameter, most vehicles spec the same overall wheel and tire circumference no matter what wheel option you have. A 205/55/16 has the same overall diameter as a 225/45/17. So does a 255/35/18. All three have a 25" diameter. You are better off buying tires designed for commuting if that is a concern.﻿

text:
MikesCarInfo I had to replace the 19” on my golf to 18” to make better daily drive. The 19” is so stiff and hits really really hard, once, a bump on highway even triggered my rain wiper! Bone shaking impact.  
My bmw has bigger suspensions so even with that 20” it feels way better but I can still feel that painful impact on the road, but I keep it for the look(not the performance)
Performance, emmm yeh maybe, but you get way more performance from wider tires and tires with more grip, and better handling from the reduced weight. But you do get wider options on larger rims.
The oem 19” is 215 wide and I put 235 on my 18”. Fuel economy difference is not sensible, both runs around 26 if I drive gently. But the road impact and driving quality is soooo different, 18” wheel just make that little car way more comfortable when hitting the broken road. And that wider sweet summer tire just grips so much better than the narrow economy continental oem tire.
Not to disagree with you completely, just add a little bit facts to consider.﻿

author: Selim Sultan Akbar

text: Personally I hate the new trend of moving the gauges and Speedo to the center of the car (Tesla model 3 & Scion xB for example) it’s more distracting to have to look over to the right or left depending on the country and it’s just cheap since they can pretty much use the same dash setup on a vehicle no matter what country it is going to. I also hate the new trend of using radar systems for auto braking, just a personal thing since I use a radar detector to avoid cops in Florida and Georgia, but it’s really annoying when ever I’m near a new minivan and my radar detector suddenly goes off full blast because I’m passing one or they got too close to the car in front of them. I’d think they would be able to use some other standardized radar frequency that radar detectors could be designed to ignore or one that police don’t use. I  also hate the new trend of using plastic for exterior body panels and bumpers, what happened to having big steel bumpers on trucks and SUV’s that wouldn’t crack if you accidentally back into a pole or someone accidentally backs into you at a low speed. Lastly I think these new LED headlights are ridiculously bright, my 2005 MINI cooper S and 2002 BMW 325xi both have Xenon HID’s in them and were required to have an auto leveling system in them to keep from blinding oncoming traffic when going up and down hills, however today’s LEDs are far brighter and seem to have no systems required to keep from blinding on coming traffic. There are systems developed to control and move headlights so that they don’t blind oncoming traffic and can recognize where an oncoming car is and move the headlights so as not to shine directly at the oncoming vehicle. Yet for some reason this is not required with the use of LED headlights.﻿

author: AJ MAG

text:
Automatic temperature control system.  This is the thing I hate most in modern cars.  Seems like I'm always trying to find the number where it will stop putting on the damn heater!  Even on the so called manual setting its still making adjustments on its own.  The old fashioned blue/red bar was so much better!  I want cold air, turn to blue, hot air, turn to red, warm air, put in the middle, and you're done!

So many other stupid things though,...
-electric parking brake
-brake hold button
-automatic wipers (the erratic pattern is annoying)
-automatic brights (damn thing keeps flashing people)
-eco button
-stereo integrated into gps screen (I just know one day I'm gonna crash trying to find a song)
-automatic brake (its too sensitive, and what if it just comes on at high speed one day)
-suspension change button (what the fuck is eco suspension?)
-seat belt alarms that keep yelling if you don't put it on!
-cruise control that brakes by itself (so damn annoying)
-push button starter (Its not comfortable keeping my keys in my pocket)

I guess the only modern features I don't hate are the heads up display and the tire low air preasure light.﻿
author: Joseph Vanni

text:
Don't buy a Chrysler and probably Dodge. My 2012 300C's HVAC is a nightmare to live with. It turns the AC on constantly due to excess humidity in the car. Regardless what you do, the AC compressor turns itself on. What's even more ridiculous is that it can barely defog the windshield when you go through a car wash. Drive in rain? Yeah, fogged windows no matter what. Car wash, fogged windows no matter what. Don't get me started about the actuators and door flaps that are prone to breaking themselves, probably due to the constant "automatic" crap switching them all the time.

It is a very quiet machine to ride in and the go button with the 5.7L under the hood works well... if it wasn't for the stupid HVAC!﻿

author: Xeridea

text:
Ignorable laborious intro
Although this may sound personal, that's not my intent - if nothing else, I sometimes like to post a devil's advocate counterpoint.
Mild snark
You do know that you can opt out of being a sniffy, dismissive, sanctimonious Luddite, right? (I'm not saying it's easy, but it can be done. Some argue that honey is a better attractant than vinegar)

Here's the beef
What if you assessed this technology strictly on "lives saved"? And what if one of those lives saved was someone you care about? Would your opinion change?﻿

These technologies dont make idiots on the roads more careless. They help people like you and me and careless drivers will be careless regardless.﻿
