author: showdonz

text: I couldn't agree more. Been the motor trade all my life and am now glad to be out of it. Got shut in a tvr once. The reason, i couldn't find the door handle because there wasn't one. I eventually found an obscure electric button. Wow, how cool (not). Quite frankly you wasted more time trying to diagnose endless problems than actually fixing them which was usually a silly computer update. Most customers just wanted something warm and waterproof that started on request to simply get to work. One big problem worth a mention. After a certain age you may find you need reading glasses. No problem. Now i can see the satnav, digital clock, heater controls, and driving instruments, providing i don't need to look out of the windscreen. So, which is it? Look out the windscreen or check the instruments? They have even started fitting electronic park brakes to heavy trucks and you have to search an array of switches to find the right one. The stupid thing is the actual park brake on cars and trucks is still mechanical. If you haven't got enough strength to operate a mechanical park brake lever then maybe you shouldn't be driving. Sorry for droning on but i see all this techno crap for what it is. I think the motor industry is used as a proving ground for technology.﻿

author: World Bodybuilding Archive

text:
Everyone appears to be missing the REAL problem in that we are being spoon fed the notion that more tecnological "advances" are necessary especially where it concerns gradually placing the driver further away from classical direct operation of the vehicle. Little by little.were being led down the incidious path working toward driverless vehicles. Each major change is being touted as the new normal on that path. Abs brakes was the first though i have to admit they do help under experiemced drivers. The problem is that drivers arent being taught well enough and the government mistakenly sees abs as a substitute for skill. The next also has to do with braking and implies that distance sensors allow.drivers to pay less attention to the road. The other is assisted parking. How, exactly, does that feature make anyone a better driver when they no longer get the practice they need for better parking skills?
   Imho, ymmv, fwiw, etc.﻿
author: joe woodchuck

text: That's a good thing. Improvements to safety have always been because of better car tech, not because of better drivers. Humans should NOT be driving if a machine can do it better. It's the most dangerous thing you do on any day.﻿

text: @Taran Van Hemert Who designs the Machines? Humans. You are more likely to eventually have errors in the Machine rather than the individual.  Machines require consistent maintenance and upkeep.  Something people don't like to do.﻿
author: Steven Roland

text:
@Taran Van Hemert   The governments have let us all down. There is a zero effort on their part to make better drivers. Road safety isnt or shouldnt be about the vehicles, crash barriers, and a few radar deployments occasionally. Road safety is about driver awareness and skill. The vast majority of.crashes boil down to oblivion and lack of handling expertise. When i took my drivers test i simply drove arkund the block and parked in front of the dmv without hitting anything. And that was around 1963. Instead of being tested occasionally for skills, all the government does is hand out some tickets and take reports after crashes. 
   In the us alone (4% of tbe world population) we have hundreds of thousands of crashes each year half of which cause injuries, and tens of thousands of deaths. We as drivers take the primary responsibility of course, but that doesnt work obviously. The governments need to do MUCH more to make our driving experiemce safer. They need to go to the meat of the matter and get our licensed drivers in a better position to even be behind the wheel. Were simply not good enough at it in order to save the many injiries and lives that we as.a.society so nonchalantly and carelessly accept as "normal". Killing and maiming people is NEVER normal, yet we contjnue to do it.﻿

author: Ofc Bob

text:
Sure, "zero effort," aside from mandatory driver's tests, licensing, and insurance. And ever-increasing safety standards for automobile design, road design, signs, signals, crosswalks, etc. Oh, and speed limits, school zones, speed bumps, and traffic cops. No. It's unfair to call that "zero effort."

Should licensing requirements be more strict, and require renewal every few years, so that we don't have nearly-blind grandmas on the roads, crashing into things they can't see? Yeah, probably. 

But self-driving cars are THE BEST SOLUTION to a safer driving experience. They are already significantly better drivers than most people. Governments are passing more and more laws that allow self-driving cars onto the roads.

And yet, you rage against it. What's really going on here, is that YOU think that YOU are a good driver -- better than most people! And you are probably right. But not everyone is as skilled as you. And not everyone will NEED to be that skilled, IF they just take the bus, train, or use a self-driving car.﻿

The infotainment system has been the one main reason that I refuse to buy a new car. I love custom audio, a decent sub, and a really good DAC in my reciever. I like physical knobs that I can manipulate without looking and analog gauges that use simple voltage directly from sensors. When auto manufacturers decided to mate the HVAC, reciever and car info into one ugly, unusable, driver distracting device that is hard to, they fucked over people like me.
I may not get the best gas mileage and I may not get the cutting edge technology of self driving lane sensing "Best" car, but at least I have something that I can have fun with.﻿

author: Trucker Mississippi Reject

text:
I will pass on replacing today's automatic transmissions that cost $7,000 and usually a lot more to repair/replace and a lot of times have difficulties getting more than 50,000 miles on them without a lot of expensive maintenace; software upgrades; repair and/or replacement.   There is reason why you no longer see warranty's on the new stuff going beyond 60,000 miles for the power train but hey for another $1500+ they will sell you an  extended warranty and gladly add to your debt, payments, and the time to it takes to payoff....  

Replacing clutchs' is usually a pretty good sign that someone does not know how to drive a manual transmission properly.    I have owned some past cars and trucks with manual transmissions that have gone 400,000+ miles and never touched the clutch/manual transmission including currently a Ford Ranger with 210,000 on it - no problems. 

Yes I have driven semi-tractors thru and around not only the cities you mention but add New York City, Washington, DC and Boston too - all manuals and no issues - over 20 years ago. 

3 years ago where I work we had to add a tractor to our fleet for pulling a 52' flat bed trailer loaded with over 20 tons of equipment.  

Showed the "youngins' how to drive a manual as well as explained to them in very intricate detail we were not spending an extra $15,000+ or more for an automatic because they were lazy - time to go find different employment then. 

Amazing how 4 of the guys since then - their personal trucks and cars are now manual transmissions....     Just amazing...   @Trucker Mississippi Reject﻿
author: MarlinMR7

text: +Dance4lifeBR There isn't anything wrong with automatic transmissions, What's wrong with automatics??﻿
author: 57HarleyDavidson

text:
Go back and read my previous comment in that there is not much wrong with today's automatics as long as they are still under warranty.  

When they are not under warranty and have issues which a lot of them due not long after they are out of warranty - spending $7,000 or more is very easily done. 

Manual transmissions though - warranty or not - have a difficulty getting to even 1/2 of that cost & unless driven by someone who does not know how to drive a manual will usually far outlast an automatic regardless of the manufacturer.  

Go ask someone how much one of those 9-speed transmissions in Chrylser/Jeep products costs to repair or replace?  Ford's new 10-speed automatics.  

Unless you have just lots of money to blow/waste so as to impress others - spending/borrowing $30,000 on a new truck/car today is easy and for that kind of money - would expect not having to buy an extended warranty as well as for it to last 10+ years with proper care and maintenace. @57HarleyDavidson﻿

text:
You hit the nail on the head for me.  I'll reject a car solely on this facet.  It's freaking dangerous, because it makes blind spots bigger and bigger.  When I drive a fairly modern car, I tend to get nervous.  Between the enormous headrests and the tiny or nonexistent back windows, I can't see anything when I look over my shoulder to change lanes.

My '94 Cherokee was like driving a glass bubble.  I could see everything out of it.  My 2010 Rav4 is still pretty good as is my mom's 2006 Escape.  But, holy crap, if you look at the next generations of those models, the visibility is just awful by comparison.﻿

author: Stinky Cheese

text: @Stinky Cheese Please before you insult, consider different geography. I don't discount that it doesn't matter where you live, but in the Portland Oregon metro area freezing rain (with the exception of traces of freezing rain) is ALWAYS caused by sub-freezing air coming through the Columbia River Gorge (which is east of here) from eastern Washington/Oregon undercutting warmer air coming from the southwest. Sometimes it causes snow but we are close enough to the ocean that it is more usually freezing rain. In fact the Columbia River Gorge is in the top three spots in the world for getting freezing rain. At least four or five times a winter, at least.﻿

author: Barbecue Tech Tips

text:
Replacing the hand brake with a fucking push button. Why? I'm not even a fan of the foot pedal parking brakes so this push button crap royally pisses me off.

1) They need electricity to function, which, as most of us know, is not always available in a car.
2) They eliminate your ability to manually control your emergency brake in the event you need to. Break lines shit themselves? You got an e-brake you can use until you can get to a safe location. Not with an electronic brake.
3) Their mere existence begs the question, what is to be gained from them in the first place? Keeping people from trying to drift their mom's Ford Fusion (which is FWD anyway but it doesn't stop kids from trying)? Please, the people that do that crap irresponsibly always find a way to do other dumb shit. Hasty conclusion? Maybe. But it certainly isn't an unreasonable assertion.

My point is, electronic/push button parking brakes provide nothing useful and remove everything that is.﻿

author: Stan Rogers

text:
Great list. When you mentioned plastic Rome and gloss black, I knew instantly we can be BFFs haha! 

My list of pet peeves, mostly things that should have been better or standard by now: 

Boot (trunk) light in most cars is on the left or right side, and is NOT bright. 
How about a strip of inexpensive yet bright LEDs running on the inside top edge of the bootlid (kinda under where the rear window) 

Awkward and inaccessible spare wheels - I don't want to unpack my entire holiday by the road side to get to a spare wheel. 

Also- what's the point of an suv or seven seater having one of those thin biscuit spare wheels? How it is going to pan out when 7 people in a vehicle towing a trailer on a dirt road on holiday has to carry on with a wheel one level up from what you find on a wheelbarrow 

Ashtrays - man their shapes are useless. They could be such great charging docks for phones instead. 

Sun visors that better wrap around oreet up with the rear view mirror. Nothing as annoying as the epic game of playing dodgems with between the setting sun and your eyeball. Yes just one eyeball at a time. 

Unergonomic door handles. How hard can this be people? 

Cupholders - you'd think it's something the human race would have mastered by now, having been to the moon and all. 

Lumbar support - because why not? Skip the fake dents and 22" alloys. Give me something I can use! 

Seats that don't fold 100% flat. if the Honda Jazz can do it, anyone can.﻿

author: Konstantinos Pantos

text:
I've grown to start hating modern cars (post 2012) and I agree with this video 100%.  Really the GDI is what I hate more than anything.  For folks who dump their car when they reach 100,000 miles it's fine, but if you can't afford a new car every 4 or 5 years, you're saddled with HUGE repairs that will either cost you $1,000s or LOTS of your time.  

2012 in car terms is actually pretty old and the truly good cars like Hondas and Toyotas from the late 90s and early 2000s are starting to become ancient and really used up and let's face it if you do any kind of mileage they're not practical to keep going.  I wish someone would make a 30mpg 4 cylinder with 200hp without a Turbo that weighs under 3000#s with 17" or smaller wheels, manual transmission and no damn screens in the interior.  Basic HVAC, Speedo/Tach Water Temp, OIl Pressure and a Stereo that displays the frequency and is bluetooth enabled.  Sell it for $20,000.  (BTW Honda plenty of cars that meet that criteria 15+ years ago.  I just want one that doesn't need every seal, belt, hose replaced, a paint job and interior job.﻿

author: Stay Fr00sty

text: After I have spent 60K$ on the worst fucking terrible piece of garbage I have had in my life, namely a 2015 Acura TLX V6 SH-AWD, which is such an absolute disgrace on every imaginable point, every single time I drove this thing I was frustrated like I never imagined I could be. Now I know how "too much worthless tech" feels. I am speaking of Acura because I have been burnt so deeply in my soul with all their unreliable, cheesy, cheap and sub-par tech they put to try to justify a totally inadequate 60K$+ price tag; yet it definitely seems to be a dangerous trend in the now "way too much regulated and poisoned automotive world". Knowing what I know now, I wouldn't even have spent 20K$ on this rubbish junkyard crap. In 3 years and 50'000 km I have even lost over 40K$ because of how much this vehicle cannot hold any value. It was my 5th Acura and it was the last, sadly, every one before it were very very good cars, probably because they were made in Japan I don't know but the coincidence is weird. One thing that made me cringe more than anything else in this shit box was the transmission. The ZF 9 speed automatic. What a legendary dirt cheap unreliable and dysfunctional piece of shit. I never thought a transmission could be so utterly dumb, jerky, slow... so inefficient in every single way except saving fuel... It had one job which was to shift gears and it failed truly miserably at it. Oh and how in a sister shack they thought people like me really care about fuel economy when buying a V6 3.5L??? If you want to save fuel then go buy a Prius! Oh god how bad this thing was it should be criminalized to sell these things. I was a die hard car guy in my heart, but this time I truly had the feeling of being fucked deeply in the ass with a telephone pole after committing to spend a fortune on this mechanical disgrace. After this experience I have been searching in the darkest places to find a real car, or at least to find out if it still existed. I was lucky, I guess, boiling everything down to the only proper choice I had found: a Subaru WRX STI, without the tech package. Yes it still has a key, a manual transmission, a manual handbrake, manual adjustment for seats, big knobs and no fucking controls on unresponsive touchscreen, etc. everything seems just right and ultra solid in a beautifully simple and absolutely pleasant package. I can say I have never been more happy and satisfied with a car purchase than this one. It's like these 3 utterly painful and frustrating years (which felt like decades really) of pure hate have suddenly gave way to peace and happiness and satisfaction. The only 2 boxes my STI does not tick is the poor quality sound system and turbo lag. Everything else is just absolutely perfect and makes me smile every single time I take the wheel. Even in winter, which has already arrived here with 2 feet of snow already. Equipped with great studded snow tires, it's just so satisfying to drive and slide in every corner with absolute traction exactly when you need it.﻿

text: hey,not a bad video,some are valid points which i hate,but.... turbos,thats another story. the reason is it far more effiecient than N/A engines(im N/A guy like the 6,2 AMGengine) . so they did it due to pressure from governments around the world to  lower emmissions and improve fuel saving due to the dwindling fuel supplies.it does improve performance,fuel economy,torque for overtaking. reliability comes in when people dont do the proper warm warm up and cool down procedures. i know of reps who have covered well over 200,000 kms who havent yet had an issue with their turbos. and more,but yes , it can give hassles,make no mistake. i also know of tons of N/A cars which had bad faults of their own too(im a motor mechanic by trade for 28+years now,seen a lot too.) but a good video none the less.﻿

author: Steven Roland

text: @Steven Roland all too true. the problem we have in South Africa is that its a third world country,but yet the consumers are full of it as i see it. but thats a good thing cause here we dont stand for it. you have no idea how many campaigns we have in SA.,for these types of things. ok i worked for German and French manufacturers over the years,work for myself now though lots of high end cars,but still do bread and butter cars too. now im surprised in north america they doing that,cheap,unreliable turbos,  but  my biggest pet thing i hate,and this is my reason im an AMG guy,BMW Mcars are now using fake engine sounds. if AMG can give us exhaust noise,due to turbos,why cant BMW msport do it? also on the turbo factor,again i also blame consumers for not adhering to manufacturers recommendations. ive used cheap aftermarket turbos for tuning reasons,but kept the boost low enough for reliable running,yet when ran properly,had more than enough kick over the standard car. ive had kinda done a documented study,for myself,on two cars i did. both ran cheap turbos,not badly made though,with over  170,000kms and 195,000kms on it without a hickup. maybe i put it together with reliable running in mind. not one coolant issue,nothing. but they start up and let idle before driving and let it idle again before switching off without revving up in the warm up phase and cool down phase. but great communicating man!!!!﻿

author: David Rubin

text:
Regarding the upper placed screens, I see no issue if it does not restrict the view. I always thought the ones places lower had no point since you had to move your view as low as the stick to view the screen in case of using GPS, so taking your eyes off the road for enough time for stuff to happen. Never been comfortable with this.
Regarding the turbo everything, it started because of Europe's retarted emissions laws, therefore the philosophy was to reduce engines, but because the car needs a certain power to run a certain way and the building materials kind of weigh the same they needed to turbo, otherwise they would obtain those mini 1.25 l engine as per 2007-8 Fiesta that barely accelerates with 4 people inside. I guess the turbo trend was directed towards other markets as US and Asia. But I must say turbo+diesel is a great idea: mine is a 1.5 dCI and I love it: enough power from diesel, decent acceleration due to turbo. On .998 eco boosts engines - pretty sure the engines will not hold for 10 years of constant use.﻿

author: Bryan White

text:
Cranky Pants - What planet have you been living on? The truth is when factoring for inflation cars cost pretty much exactly the same as they did back when I started driving in the mid 70’s. Not only that but you get A LOT more for the same price. Modern cars are not only infinitely safer but they also handle better, are more fuel efficient, have more horsepower per liter, and have a lot more creature comforts than cars of the 60’s and 70’s. Not to mention the fact that they don’t require constant tune ups and they will go much farther before requiring a total engine rebuild. 

I do agree with you on some points however. For example, although I love technology, I still like a physical knob to control the radio volume and the AC fan. Luckily some car companies are finally wising up and going back to knobs for certain things.﻿

author: Salman Shami

text:
I have to disagree with a few of these:
1. Floating screens. I think a lot of them look really good. I like the clean, sleek, dashboards that aren't too bulky, and not putting the screen inside the dash allows them to do keep the dash small. 
2. Fake noise. I think it's a necessary evil. New cars are so well insulated that you literally cannot hear the engine and it takes a lot of fun out of the drive. I think audi's execution of this with the soundaktor gives the best and most natural feeling sound.
3. Infotainment systems allow you to control tons of features without cluttering up the dash with hundreds of buttons. Again, a necessary change that people may not like, but it's the most efficient way to control multiple systems. 
4. Small turbo engines. The death of large v6 and v8 engines cannot come soon enough. The amount of power and fuel economy these new 4 cylinder turbos can achieve is amazing. There's nothing better than having nearly 300hp on tap and still getting a pleasant 35mpg on the highway. If some manufacturers fuck it up, that's their own fault. Don't blame the entire concept because a few companies have poor execution.﻿

author: michael tuemose

text:
The number of people I know with so little money to spare, if they put this kind of thought into making cars truly as cheap as they safely and reliably can rather than pop out handles, tuned engine noise, and fancy touch screens, they'd make the real killing.  Rich people have as many cars as they want.  The desperately poor want to stop taking the bus, but they've over-estimated the bottom of the market, or they just aren't serving it.  They could pick up a lot of the used car market if they could offer real new reliability at prices that require new-feature level engineering.

Also, whoever makes a new old car, not a re-immagining, or PT cruiser, but whoever busts out the old molds and makes a new car from the 50s 60s or 70s at regular mass-produced prices will sell all the cars.  people are starved for an interesting car that isn't the Cube.﻿

author: asherael

text: Can I add extremely complex, oversized, and expensive headlights to this list? Over the past 15ish years headlight assemblies have gotten so massive that they often bulge upwards over the hood of the car so they are directly exposed to sunlight, causing the (ultra low quality plastic) outer lenses to decay within as little as two years of a car being on the road (as seen on my neighbor's 2016 Prius). In addition to this, headlight manufacturers no longer sell lenses to replace sun-damaged ones so the only option after the lens cracks is to buy a whole new headlight ($2100 each if you have a BMW F10 5 series...). Typing this makes me so pissed off lol. I just restored the headlights on my 1998 BMW 7 series using brand new thick GLASS lenses ($100 shipped from Europe!!) and new chrome reflectors for 1/20th of the time and cost to restore the lights on a newer BMW... while still having a better looking car than anything BMW has built since then. Rant over, thanks for listening﻿

text: Agreed. My 16 Spark has one of those dual-mode CVTs where if you mash your foot down it uses simulated shift points but ease into it and it sits at one low-ish RPM and stays there until you’re done accelerating. My biggest complaint is that the dual-mode electronics are easily confused by everyday behavior. It can’t cope with rolling stops. It doesn’t like being thrashed on the freeway (and with 98hp to work with, you have to mash it if you don’t want to get run over). If it was just a simple twist & go style CVT it would work much better.﻿

text:
CVT stands for continuous variable transmission. It is a transmission type that has two rollers and a belt connecting them to each other, and they expand and shrink depending on your speed; there are no certain gears like 1, 2, 3, etc that the regular transmission shifts between. I know I suck at explaining things hehehe. 

the main benefit of it is that it has a better "efficiency & fuel economy"﻿

author: Vinc Montecristo

text:
@Julia Set I'm pretty sure that the hand brake isn't and hasn't been an emergency brake for at least the past 35 years. I have no doubt that if you look in any car manual from 1989 or newer it will tell you that the brake is meant to keep the car in place while parked, and not to be used for stopping the car. That is why it is represented with a P symbol. It is a Parking brake.  
The chances of a modern braking system failing to stop a car after a failure is basically zero unless the driver is a complete idiot. If a line blows out, it will effect, at most, two wheels. You would need to perform multiple stops after the failure to pump all the fluid out.﻿

author: Mike

text: @Mike Multiple ways. Either press brakes and accelerator at the same time (clutch still being pressed). That will disengage auto hold. Touch the accelerator and gently let go of the clutch, but just so much that the car senses it. Or, I believe pushing down the handbrake button also works. Many other cars only engage auto hold for a few seconds, which I find annoying but would work too.﻿

author: muslimin karben

text:
I had an Audi. A quattro (four wheel drive). A 4.2L (V8). Oh my God the thing was so bad ass. Made me feel like the coolest person in town. 

But then the front headlight went out. And I had to remove the entire front bumper and clutch fan to replace it. 

And the transmission started to slip. But it was a built in tranny. Need very VERY specific measurements to replace the filter and oil. 

And then the planet gears busted. No more tranny. 

I've since got a Dodge Stratus. 200,000 miles (40,000 since I bought it)I andve yet to do any repairs. I could. Not. Be. Fucking. Happier. 

Goes to show, luxury does not equal reliability﻿

author: Kyle Wolfe

text: I drive a 99 Miata, my favorite and simplest car I've ever owned. Im a service writer, so im constantly driving new and old cars alike- and let me tell you some of the stupidest shit. There was an Accura that came through that required me to put a keyfob in a compartment found WITHIN the glove compartment. Just so that the vehicle would shut off its battery. Another thing im tired of, Cars that have the dial keys. (the ones that look like a damn stove knob) that you cant turn on unless you have a key fob. If you want to add in new tech, go ahead and add it in. Atleast make it useful, and something that adds to the car. If I have to have the key fob to turn the stove knob on my new car, why not just give me a keyfob with a key on it that I have to keep track of? Instead of putting a stupid fucking dial in there where they key would go. Auto start/stop just wastes the starter, and another thing- overly complicated seats. Can you really not pull on a simple latch to move your seat back and forth? Had a buddy who blew a fuse in his seats and it cost him $650 for a new seat. Just for one fuse to one of the 8 cushions. At the end of the day, its simply planned obsolescence, fill a car with items that easily break so that you get more money out of it after the purchase date. Get 30,000 for a new car, and then get a couple more thousand with repairs down the road. My Miata has a simple dash, a simple entertainment system, and a simple shifter. Thats all it needs.﻿

text: Lexus has a new commercial saying something along the lines of them testing a hybrid system for 6 million miles, it’s misleading and brought back memories to the early 2000’s when Kia also had a commercial and mislead people to believe that a single car drove a million miles across America and you should buy it because it will go a million miles.. what they ended up doing in those test is driving quite a few 200k and total all of them combined did 1 million miles and I’m certain Lexus did the same thing.. misleading car ads are all the rage right now ..I like simple infotainment set ups where it’s just touch screen radio stuff I like digital speedometers I like all the safety equipment and I even like CVTs I find regular automatics harsh after driving a cvt ..I agree piano black interior stuff is awful ...not sure what happened but around 2005ish blind spots became all the rage and I’m over that ..I had 2 Nissan Sentras, a 92 and a 94 and you could see everything out of the back window and side windows and the mirrors it was great ..I drive a 2015 Nissan Rogue Select now and I can’t see shit I have to do a full turn and if you drive a little ricer low rider I still can’t see you lol ..first experienced the blind spot rage in a 2009 Ford Fusion and a 2010 Galant and pretty much every other newish car I’ve driven since ..2014 Camaro has been the worst I’ve experienced yet lol ..I’ve enjoyed Nissan I’ve only ever purchased them .. I’ve seen a lot of fuss about the CVTs going out but I want to say that’s lack of maintenance it says change the fluid every 30k miles and I’ve seen a video where the guy never touched the fluid and it went out at like 180k miles and that seems normal for any automatic that’s never been maintained.. 4 of my nissans have had 300k miles and still going so I will stick to what’s worked for me﻿

author: Doudymac

text:
I only agree with about half this list.  And sorry, you're full of misinformation - my source:  I'm a GM/Ford Service Tech.

1.  Auto Stop/Start is not dumb, fake induction noise is dumb, yes.  Auto stop/start is used to eliminate the wasting of gas at long stops, and thus eliminating the emissions waste.  To top this off, the feature can be MANUALLY TURNED OFF (Plebians).  These vehicles use a Bi-Directional Crank Position Sensor to compensate for the very slight backspin of a crankshaft when you shut an engine off.  Computer knows where the crankshaft is during the shutoff and even after.  They also use a secondary battery, or an AGM battery to keep electronic features on, and the vehicle will not shut off if the battery is too weak, or a huge collection of very important conditions have not been met, including engine temp, vehicle speed attained since last shut off, and climate control load.

2.  The Cruze does not suffer a "Known turbo issue".  The turbos on those vehicles going out is only an indication that someone didn't take care of their freaking car.  DexOs oil changes at 6k miles AS THE OWNER'S MANUAL SAYS, and not shutting your car off the moment you put it in park after putting it under heavy boost loads will make only random failure occur.  There's plenty of very high mileage Cruzes out there on the original turbo, and last, manufacturers are NOT just 'slapping them on there'.  GM makes all of their turbos internally, an engineer did his job to come up with the turbo, and they came up with a system to protect the turbo.  After the 2nd Gen Cruze, the 2015+ Malibu, the 1.4T Dart, and many other modern turbo cars actually use the cooling system to maintain the turbo temperature, instead of just the oil feeds that lubricate their impellers.

The only true part of the Cruze statement is the cooling system issues.  Yes, it has cooling system issues.  Water pump, water outlet, and the thermostat bypass hose tend to leak.  Water pump is the only one that's really notorious, though, and GM rectified the other issues in Gen 2.  

Fuel economy standards are forcing manufacturers to up the game on their economy.  You can't stick a 1.0 liter engine in a modern car and expect it to get out of its own way.  35mpg is about the best most manufacturers could get without Variable Valve Timing coming alone, Direct Injection, and better engineered engines. So no, sorry, they're not slapped on to get more power.  They are a step that manufacturers resorted to due to overwhelming pressure to up emissions and economy.

3.  Yeah, fake noise can get out.  After working on a lot of these cars, some of the over complicated systems are ridiculous.  Radio controls and some BUS systems are ridiculous.﻿

author: Andrew Case

text:
I hate screens in cars. The fact they want to replace knobs and levers with a touch screen is terrible. Say I want to turn on the ac towards my feet, I turn two knobs, and don't have to take my eyes off the road because I can FEEL the controls. You can't FEEL controls on a touch screen, you have to look, and take your eyes off the road. Plus, I noticed they're very time consuming. Like just turning on the radio takes a good 5 seconds (which is VERY long when driving). With analog controls, it takes less than one.

The other thing is red turn signals. Manufacturers have started using brake lights as turn signals at the same time. It's the ambiguity of it all! Discerning a light by its colour will always be easier and quicker than by its behaviour.﻿

author: Chiranjib Biswas

text:
"People don't wanna spend $70 on a tire"  Ain't that the truth.  I remember being in a tire&lube shop waiting for an oil change, when a woman came in for a tire repair.  When they took the tire off the rim they found that the screw she ran over had gone in through the tread at an angle and lodged itself in the sidewall rather badly.  I don't know how long she was driving on it like that, but when they showed it to her I could see the sidewall damage from across the room.  Anyway, when they gave her a quote for a new tire she didn't like it and told them to just put the old tire back on and she'd go somewhere else.  Of course, they can't do that.  If they put a tire with a cut up sidewall back on the vehicle it would leave them liable if she has a blowout and gets in an accident.

I had to put up with her screaming at them for the next fifteen minutes while they did my oil change.﻿
